number of helpful: 10 of 13 people (77%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 1, 2013
												Medieval II Total War is a good game, a fun game. But when put beside it's predecessors, it's also a very small game. I am not talking about size here, or even the scope of the game but more it's advancement over the previous installment. It's that same question you always have to ask yourself every time a franchise you enjoy comes out with a new installment.Should I get the new one or just replay the old one? In the case of Medieval II the answer is, you might as well go play another campaign in Rome.While Medieval by itself is a great game that promises hours of entertainment it doesn't really do anything that you couldn't already do in Rome. Most of the new features are minor in nature or simply cosmetic the lack of advancement is instantly noticeable when you realize that Medieval even managed to bring over a few bugs from Rome that were never quite fixed.For the newcomers to the series, Medieval II Total War is a mix between a real time strategy game and a turn based grand strategy game. The turn based aspect focuses mainly on empire management, improving your cities, raising and moving armies and conducting diplomacy with other factions. This area has traditionally been the weak spot of Total War games and Medieval makes no changes there. The system is clunky and bugged, the AI is completely worthless and the diplomacy might as well not have been included. Anything the grand strategy aspect of Total War tries to do has already been done a thousand times better in pretty much every other grand strategy game.But then again, you don't buy a Total War game for the cerebral strategy. You buy it for the guts and glory of the the real time battles where armies clash and legion perish all for the hope of victory and while the satisfaction you get from a successful maneuver is still present so is the complete lack of any sort of intelligence on the part of your opponents. As with all other Total War games, the AI is incapable of doing anything beyond the classic attack move with no concern for formation, flanking or skirmishing leading to almost every battle being a cakewalk unless you are terribly outnumbered.Graphically the series still impress although the uniformity with your units is beginning to show, the sounds work well enough that you are never taken out of the action and the soundtrack is acceptable most of the time.All in all Medieval II is a good and fun game that you can spend hundreds of hours in easily. Should you buy it still comes down to that same question however. If you have never played a Total War game I would always recommend you get the newest in the series. Medieval II is still an advancement over Rome, albeit a very minor one. If you already own Rome however then there is little new for you here and you would probably be better off saving your money for further down the line when another installment in the series comes along with a more profound leap in mechanics and technology.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2016
												To start off, you should probably buy this game. I say probably, because $20 is a little pricey, but if its on sale for $10 or under get it! It is a great strategy game with two main modes. The campaign map is like an overall strategy game where you try to conquer the world, and the tactical battles are individual battles where you control an army. Although the graphics are outdated, the strategy in this game is priceless. Played a game as Portugal, and first killed Spain. Then fought and made peace with France, then went south and killed the Moors, then kept going east and killed sicily, kept going and am currently about to kill Egypt. I also conquered Rome from Sicily and returned it to the pope, who became my bestie for all of 2 turns until he died. The next pope hated me, but at the moment I am not excommunicated. And so,If you read it through this far you probably should  buy the game.Just do it.Update:I just discovered the plethora of mods for this game, and they are truely amazing. Mods like third age make it seem like an entirely new game, and add so much replayability to the game. Another great reason to get this game.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												Medieval II... Wooft. Got to be the best Total War game there is atm.- = Negatives+ = Positives+ Of course the graphics and mechanics are a little outdated (but are still better than Atilla.. Just sayin).+ Battles are ♥♥♥♥ing amazing! Unit Variety is not a problem here at all.+ Campaign is extremely detailed. Still has the best UI for a Campaign I think.+ Mods are amazing (Third age and Call of Warhammer)+ Factions all have interesting and different units from eachother.+ DLC has 3x more content than the original game (3 new campaign packs and units).+ Most interesting era (in my opinion).+ Most units are balanced.- Two handed glitch in Vanilla game. (Not in Expansions).+ Castles and settlements are ♥♥♥♥ing amazing.- Cavalry (If you can use them well) seems slightly OP in some ways.- Lack of special abilities for units.+ UI is easy to get used too.- AI is extremely stupid if you don't turn the difficulty up.+ Familiar factions and units. Such as Scottish Highlanders and English Longbowmen ect.+ Gameplay seems extremely smooth compared to more recent TW games. Might just be me though.+ Great endgame challenges. Which you can find out for yourself XP.- Mods can be quite a challenge to install if you don't know what your doing. But there are good tutorials out there.- There are a few factions that are more powerful than others, but that is to be expected.. *cough cough* Venice.And there you go! Did this help? If it did be sure to like :)

content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												Medieval 2 total war was released in 2006 and it still holds itself well. The graphics do not feel dated and the game mechanics are similar to other total war games, making it easy to get into. The singleplayer suffers due to the stupid A.I. but there is enough variety to keep you entertained and there are mods that improve the campaign game further.The greatest part of this game however is its dedicated community and its multiplayer experience. The multiplayer is still very much alive and kicking. Whether you are new to total war or experienced in similar games you will fing something for you. From siege battles, 1v1, team battles or free for alls, you can usually keep the multiplayer experience varied through a variety of game types, factions and rule sets.There is a host of youtube commentators that give this game the support and attention it deserves. It was a great investment when I got the game all those years ago, and is definitely worth a go, especially if you can pick it up on offer.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												For how old this game is it's still one of the best strategy games I've ever played. The game starts in the dark ages and progresses through the Renaissance. You take control of a faction (the Holy Roman Empire, Egypt, England, France to name a few) and run the trade, religion (including joining/launching Jihads and Crusades), family (via marrying into other  royal families or having worthy generals married into yours), exploration (once the technology is available you can lead your faction to settling the new world) and military. When battles occur you can choose to skip them or fight them in real time which is a blast. This game has so much in it and it is so immersive that it is definately worth playing even now.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 11, 2016
												I must have played thousands of hours of the vanilla version of Medieval 2. Then I discovered the mods.A review of the game, as it is now for 20 Euro, is that it is still a great strategy game with awesome tactical battles. If you haven't played any Total War, then I would recommend to start with Medieval 2. There are newer games, but those are tweaked away from what I think are the best features in the Total War series. And yes, buy the collection so you get Kingdoms (4 new game modes that each feels like a proper expansion, compatibility with Third Age mod) for 3 Euro more.My only major complaint with Medieval 2 is the AI. The difficulty scaling is just how soon the AI will declare war on you. Even if you have a tiny neighbour that you've been allied with for hundreds of years and protected through dozens of war, it is only a matter of time before they will declare war on you. The tactical AI will form a solid battle line and try to flank you with cavalry. And do exactly that in nearly all situations.Longbowmen (and some other archers as well, can't remember which ones) are also way overpowered, since the most lethal thing known to (horse)man in this game are wooden stakes, and longbowmen can plant those in the deployment phase of a battle.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
 Even though Medieval 2: Total War was released in 2006 it still rocks with the best of today!The graphics are a touch out dated but the strategic game play is powerful fun when comanding a massive army about to seige a castle. You order to fire the catapults! You then witness flaming boulders slam into the castle gates and walls! The sound will cause you to turn up the volume!  Your next order is for the footmen to carry ladders to the castle walls and attack the archers! They yell as they run towards possible death and yet none show second thought. Just then the catapults have just destroyed the castle gates and your horsemen charge full speed and enter the castle. Sorry, lost my self in memories of M2:TW. This game is that good with no signs of fading! How do I know this? Well, I bumped into Medieval II - Total War Gaming Group (MTWGG) that plays regularly and will be happy to help you. They are great international people and an even better group leader named Dark Angel. So when you purchase M2:TW make sure you check them out.  Here is a link to their group page. http://steamcommunity.com/groups/MTWGG Buy the game, join MTWGG and enjoy some of the best strategic gaming on Steam right now!  :)

content:
Posted: June 12, 2016
												My god this game is epic.Alright so I was playing as England and I first went and got York, Dublic, ect.Then i went and declared war on scotland, that war lasted all of about four turns.Then, and I know I had this game for 63 hours but I actually did not ever complete the game.I stuck to custom and multiplayer battles. But anyway I went and fought France. Now I did notdo it out of the blue. the French were always threatening to invade me unless I paid a tax, normally like560 or something. So anyway that was really cool. Massive armies clashing against eachother. Choosingthe better ground, it was like a game of thrones war. I gave my characters backstories and named the battles. I will give an example of one at the end. But anyway I was playing a short campaign and when I finished it and toppled the final French castle with the Milan and Holy Roman Empire at my side I suddenly get this epic music in ears.Next thing I know Im in a throne room, like, once again, game of thrones and the Narrator goes on about how epic the"English Empire" Is and how King Rufus, first of his name, protector of all of Christendom is the "Best king that will ever be. So yeah that was epic. Do I recommend this game? @£$% yeah I would! But anyway onto the battle.King Rufus looks over his men. Wearing their mail coifs and wielding swords of iron and steel. Infront of them stands an army of scots. It was led by a family member, he paused for a moment. He could not remember the mans name. He lined his spearmen in a straight line facing the highlanders and the rabble. Rufus saw the man Edenheart, he thought to himself Edenheart. Rufus ordered his men to fire upon the now charging highland horde. Two hundred arrows filled the sky, near blocking out the sun. Many casualties were theirs. Then the highlanders crashed into a line of iron spears. The line broke. He ordered his border horse to chase down the fleeing enemy. Then the young family member seeing the battle lost, rallied a small portion of men and charged down the hill in which his steed stood upon. Rufus stroked his horses mane. He then road through the line of men and crashed into the unsupecting scots. He met the young man, Edenheart. With one stroke of his blade he cut the man down. He looked at the young man that now lay in the mud, he had no remorse. He jumped down and cut the head of the man. He ordered one of the spear men to stab it unto their spear and march it around like a banner. Edenheart was brother to the king of the scots, the king that had killed his own father. He would have his vengenece no matter how many lives it took. FinPs (Sorry for my English :))

content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												THIS GAME IS AMAZING!!!!     so yeah i'm sure by my title you can guess where i stand on my opinion of the game. Now before i begin i will say that i have played many games of this category. for instance there is nearly all the total war titles and europa univeralis 4, hearts of iron 3. So i am not unfamiliar with this (and for those who are you will find it is VERY easy to get into). Pretty much everything about this game is perfect i mean the gameplay when you command your troops in battle is so immersive and spotless it is hard to find a complaint. Not to mention this game is weirdly more advanced and realistic compared to later total war game, like empire total war and napoleon or even the newest rome 2. I mean you actually have to have your diplomats move and not just be lazy and click a button and open up the diplomatic menu. Not to mention the soldiers actually act like people! now if you haven't noticed the troops from shogun 2 and rome 2 DESPERATLEY need to take notes from this MASTERPIECE of a game. the troops in Medieval 2 move so fluently it is unreal, in rome 2 they feel like bricks with legs, shogun 2 (and empire and napoleon) are slightly better with this which adds to my earlier topic of how earlier games are better than the new ones. empire and napoleon makes more sense with how they soldiers move though because of the timeline, shogun 2 kinda does because it does have a couple gun regiments. but rome 2 i have no idea.And another thing is that Medieval 2 is not arcady like rome 2 and empire napoleon and shogun 2. in rome 2 there is a timer in the fortress in a siege so if you just have one dude step in that stupid circle you will win in 2min it is crazy, now i know there is one in Medieval 2 but considering it is in they WAY back of the fortress it is not even there. another thing is the maps are very different and unique and are just generally much better than what i've seen in rome 2. (by the way if you are wondering why i am comparing so much to rome 2 it is because it is the newest game of the total war series and this just goes to show that pretty graphics can only take you so far, because that is all rome 2 is to me) Also the gameplay in the battles in Medieval 2 are so much more stratigic and are just generally perfect in everyway possible, unlike rome 2. Now the whole point of the total war games is to have an easy political view game and a very complicated and stratigic battling system in between. THAT IS WHAT A TOTAL WAR GAME IS SUPPOSED TO BE LIKE. (which is why Medieval 2 is so amazing) in rome 2 the battling system is so horride and awful it makes me want to puke, and the diplomatic gameplay just.....i can't even describe my disgust with that, in Medieval 2 it is just so perfect and amazing that my only explanation for how good it is, is probably that a god crafted Medival 2. Now i could go on and on about how Medieval 2 is the best total war game i've played. Like the music is so amazing and inspiring and immersive. Medieval 2 also is SUPER IMMERSIVE AND PERFECT IN NEARLY EVERY WAY POSSIBLE! now i could talk for the rest of my life on how good this game is, but i am pretty sure that whoever read this long probably got the idea already, so yeah Medieval 2 is 10/10 in my book

content:
Posted: December 5, 2015
												Medieval 2: Total War is a highpoint of the Total War series. It is certainly the longest supported and one of the most highly modded of the Total War games. On a surface level it's an empire management game requiring economic management of cities and regions. On a secondary level it's a diplomacy game, requiring careful decision making regarding allies and opponents as well as currying favour with the powers that be i.e. the Papacy and thirdly it still blends in the faster paced action of the tactical battles that allows one to actively witness and control sieges and battle upon the open field. As an older game the graphics are poor but not terrible, due to the usually zoomed out perspective, that doesn't show up poor unit models. It's challenging and has only the barest introduction for new players, requiring learning through trial and error, (which is more effective), and has a UI that contains as little or as much detail as you like, depending on how far through the menus you progress, something newer games tend to try to oversimplify and thus lack detail. Medieval 2: TW is more than likely going to be around for a long time yet, with it's continuing active player base, and it is that more than any review online that speaks for the quality of this game.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Once upon a time, I had carved out a worthy empire in northern Germany, and Scandanavia, and was steadily working up to a war againist the HRE, until they finally struck and began to attack. By then, I was having horrible money issues, due to poor upkeep, and an insane abundance of generals. I had an army far superior to the HRE's but they had immense numbers, I carved my way through atleast 3 armies before my own was reduced to less than a hundred and I was forced to retreat. But, with no cash to rebuild a defence I decided it was time to leave behind the dozen generals and the deadly enemy I had made for a much more peaceful living. My ally, Venice gladly traded Tripoli to me for all my cities. In no time, I was able to stablize myself with just 2 generals, all the rest died in a horrible accident with the English navy. However, I had no room to expand and was forced to battle Sicily. It was suprisingly easy after I had taken Tunis. But the Mongols had begun to capture every city they could. They wanted Tripoli too, so I easily gave it to them, their navies and armies scared me. But before I left, I renamed the city to Mongoliassholia. Now, in Tunis I built up my economy and made up enough money to get 3 Carracks to sail me to Sicily and Sardinia, which I easily conquered as the Sicilians somehow lost their entire forces defending Tunis. After much conquering, I had Corsica, Florence too, and was well on my way to finish off Sicily off east. When Portugal, and Milan decided I was in the way of their expansion. By then Germany, Egypt, and the Turks had been destroyed. Scotland reduced to Ireland, the Netherlands, and a city in the Baltics somehow. Portugal had made Spain and the Moors into vassals. Russia had been reduced to their original size, by the Timurids. The Mongols stretched out from Tripoli, to the Ukraine. Venice, once a power thanks to me had been too stretched out, and France, had managed to move all the way out to Poland, and Hungary, and were steadily taking out the rest of Venice in Europe, and eagerly awaiting to finish the ones off in Scandanavia. They wouldn't attack me though, we were in good standing. Now, as my eagar axemen, and sword-bearers are ready to invade Bologna, the Mongols come knocking again, and the max turns are reached. This is where I ended my game. Sandwiched between enemies. My allies, far gone. The moral of the story is use condoms, so your generals don't make 20 god damn children.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												Medieval 2: Total War is the 4th game in the Total War series and was released in 2006. It shows it's age a little when standing next to the newer games in the series, but is still fun to play. Medieval 2 is set in the latter half of the middle ages, between 1080 and the 1500's. Medieval 2, only allows you to play as 5 Factions when you first start out. All of these factions were the historically powerful factions of the age. Defeating additional factions unlocks them for play up to 17 different playable factions in total through campaign mode.A mixture of real-time tactics and strategy, as well as turn-based gameplay, exploration and expansion, Medieval 2 is fun to play, but is starting to show it's age a little. I suppose we are getting spoiled in 2015 with games that have realistic looking characters; However, it is still fun and would be recommended to anyone who enjoys the Total War series.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												My favourite and most played of the Total War series, with probably closer to 400 hours, before I bought again on Steam.A stand out element is the music – I have been known to boot up into the main menu, just to savour the fantastic score, I believe entitled “Time And Again”, accompanied with the crashing of thunder and lightning, and watching the silhouetted troops march by.Part of the reason Medieval II (and Kingdoms) is my favourite, is likely because I just have not invested the time in the newer incarnations (the following 2 just didn’t grab me), but undoubtedly the combat style of the era is much more to my taste.All in all a really great game, with more than enough to keep you enjoying well beyond the purchase price. Fully recommended.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												M2TW is a fun cheap game, that will cause you to stay up much to late telling yourself "just one more turn". The game runs well on nearly any PC and its unbelivably well-priced for how entertaining and detailed it is. Now, I am sure someone could argue that there are better RTS games out currently, but considering the release date of this game and its price it is definitely worth the buy. I would say my favorite part of the game is how many variables and details are incorporated in the logistics involved in the campaign (such as financial, military, domestic, diplomatic, and geopolitical elements). Every time I play through a campaign I learn something different.Basically, if you want an addictive and engaging RTS to play, and you want to spend as little cash as possible I would absolutely get this game.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												This game will grab you by the chin hairs, and pull you in it! The diplomacy is terrific, the battles are beautiful, and the options are steep! It's like burning raiders to death with a flamethrower! Great stuff. The campaign is insanely fun, every battle you do will affect how others think of your kingdom, and it will all affect your general, prince, king, whoever is leading your men to victory. I myself prefer to slaughter everything, as it sends a message, and it turned a loving, nice prince into a cruel, hateful one! Brilliant! My king is a tyrant, and everybody who rebels meets the same fate as the armies which attempt to destroy my castle. What I am saying is, in this game you get to be a conquerer! Trust me on this, I know my charisma is only at 4, but my perceptation is at 8. You will adore this game. This game, is the shining turd of all other Total War games.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												Probably the greatest Total War game to ever be released. Shame it didn't get the advertising campaign like Rome: Total War did. Truly an underappreciated masterpiece. My biggest wish is that Creative Assembly can achieve this level of mastery once again. If you can withstand graphics from 2006, I highly suggest playing it. As you build your kingdom over the course of 400 years, don't forget to discover America, declare a Crusade/Jihad, assassinate the last 3 heirs of a family line to take over half of their kingdom, use your recently converted christian populace to stir up unrest and rebellion in the local muslim kingdom or vice versa, develop gunpowder, have one of your priests elected pope, get excommunicated, have your merchants systematically take advantage of another nation's trade resources, assassinate your own king, and watch as everything you worked for crumbles when the Black Death hits. This game had it all.

												Even though I think Rome Total War is the best in the franchise Medieval II Total War is my personal favorite. Despite it's old age this game has an outstanding unit variety, beautiful graphics which still hold up, a huge campaign map with a great variety of factions each with different enemies to face, different problems to solve and unique warfare and units to fight with. content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												Medieval 2 is the first game in the Total War series that I have purchased, but after watching many gameplay videos on Youtube and various other sites, I had very high expectations for the game. Within less than an hour, all of my expectations were met. Medieval 2 has a fairly straight forward learning curve, and is very forgiving to those who are new to the game. With both skirmishes and a grand campaign, there is plenty to do, with many different factions to choose from, each with their own unique units and specialties. With a fantastic engine and good graphics, the game feels very realistic. The campaign is very deep, with many different agents and battles, making you come up with new strategy's every time you play. Beating the campaign unlocks the rest of the factions to play as, with you only starting with five. Overall I would rate this game as an 8/10, as there are some minor bugs.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												Don't know why I haven't gotten around to recommending this game yet since I've been playing it on and off for years, but, quite simply, Medieval 2 is a masterpiece of grand strategy.  I am a big fan of the Total War series, and I can say without question that this game has the best diplomacy and politics of any TW and the best mods for any TW game.  Whether you simply want a more refined experience in the form of mods such as Stainless Steel or a total conversion that puts you centerstage in the War of the Ring with Third Age TW, the Medieval 2 modding scene has much to offer.  Truly one of the highlights of the series and if you're a fan of the genre or just ancient history in general, buying this game is a no-brainer.  Do it now!(p.s. be sure to get Kingdoms as well)

												Total Score:  84, B (Ye Olde Pretty Awesome!)Graphics and Art:  7Sound and Music:  5Story and Plot:  7Controls:  9Creativity and Uniqueness:  9Mood and Immersion:  9Length, Content, and Replayability:  10Functionality:  10Character Choice and Customization:  9Challenge:  9Are you ready to breach and butcher, my lord?  I know I am!  There are many games that allow you to wield a sword or axe or bow, but, really, why do that when you can wield thousands of them?  The beauty of Medieval II, like the rest of the Total War series, is that it does an out-standing job of capturing the tactical nuances of combat from pre-modern eras, as well as doing the strategic piece pretty well also, insofar as you can manage your cities in a variety of different ways as well as control agents.  This is definitely a game for those that like to think and who like a game that rewards them for thinking.  MTW2, like the rest of the TW series, has diplomacy, agents, merchants, assassins, and priests, and captures the dimensions that these bring to the strategy.  However, these elements, like all others, are there, ultimately, as an element related to combat, which is where this series shines.  It is called Total War, after all, not Total Diplomacy, or Total Economic and Cultural dominance.  Additionally, the game events throw at you some unique challenges of the period which really do quite a lot to keep the challenge and pressure on even as your empire becomes more and more mighty.  For the period, the graphics are incredible, and like other TW games, it's a lot of fun to just zoom in and watch your units work.  All in all, this series is unique and indispensible to the PC gaming world.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												This is the only review I've ever written for a game on Steam. After playing Medieval 2, Rome, Empire, and Rome 2, I can safely say that Medieval is still my favorite in the series. Yes, the later iterations ARE prettier. This game was released in 2006 after all. However, in my opinion, you can't beat the game engine they used. The Warscape engine that is utilized by the newer games (empire onwards) has taken a loooooong time to reach the same level of melee combat satisfaction that I got from M2. Sure, there are no fancy one v one animations. BUT, those animations also wrecked havoc with how many battles played out. I don't think I ever saw two soldiers gang up on one soldier in any game other than M2 and Rome 1. Battles are played out more by training stats, upgrades, and tactics vs. a boat ton of special abilities and badas* animations. I know there are plenty of people who won't agree, but it's just my experience. The biggest reason why I always come back to this game is the modding community. I had the game running on a virtual version of windows on my mac (years before the mac version was released) JUST so I could play Third Age Total War. Not to mention all the unit mods, engine and animation tweaks, etc. This is still probably the most mod friendy total war game out there. I spent dozens of hours over the last 8-9 years compiling units and tweaks to get my game just right, enduring hundreds of coding errors and game re-installs. Little by little (and somehow without taking over my life) Medieval 2 became a near-perfect game. And this is a guy with little to no mod creation or coding experience whatsoever. All in all, it's a wonderful game that won't be surpassed until they potentialy do a new Total War in the Medieval setting. It's perfectly fine without mods, but if you're like me and discovered just how awesome the modding community is, it's the best Total War game to mod in my opinion.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												The successor to the classic Rome: Total War, Medieval II: Total War is a fun game that introduces new concepts and deals with a period of time from shortly after the Norman Conquest of England to the Age of Discovery. Among other events that will be affecting you in this time period are the Mongols showing up, gunpowder being introduced, the Black Death arriving and killing most of your population (don't worry it does the same to everybody), the Timurids following their Mongol ancestors, and then the beginning of the Age of Discovery. Castles and Cities develop in two separate ways, and produce different units.If playing a Catholic nation, you have to deal with the Pope. He can make or break your nation, so keep an eye on your approval rating with him. After a victory, most of the factions are then unlocked. They are also unlocked individually if you happen to be the one to land the killing blow.Side note: If you do unlock all the nations, three are the Moors, Egypt, and the Turks. Do take care of your volume at that time, because when you click a unit, move them, or attack with them, they do have a slight vocalization. Which at times could make people nervous (about killing infidels and the like). Some who hear you play may also get a bit nervous when you play the Holy Roman Empire (or the First Reich).

content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
-Quick Review-Medieval II: Total War is a Medieval strategy game developed by The Creative Assembly and released 2006. Medieval II: Total War is full of country-micromanaging with strong emphasis on historical context, strategies, and battle planning.-Detailed breakdown review-Story: There is a Campaign where the player takes on the role of the selected nation, and develops said nation militarily and economically. The story is generally trying to follow historically accurate events, foes, allies, and important key leaders.


Tutorial - Uploaded for the review 
A Screenshot of Medieval II: Total War
By: Atratzu




Gameplay: There are two game modes in Medieval II: Total war (or in this genre of Strategy game in general): Battle Mode, when it's opposing armies clashing against each other. The other mode requiring just as much skill as battle strategy (probably requiring more) is World Mode, where you navigate the map, edit city construction, politics, religion,  army movement, and much more.There's a lot to learn going into Medieval II: Total War, if you haven't played any of the previous franchise games. (Which I hadn't; this was my personal first Total War game) The game starts out with a tutorial campaign explaining basic combat concepts to battle warfare and gives the player a rudimentary introduction to camera movement, and unit controls. While the tutorial is effective at helping you learn, there is far more information to learn about the franchise inner workings, and for that: your best friend is the in game advisers (I like to think of them as my F1 key).


Map mode - Uploaded for the review 
A Screenshot of Medieval II: Total War
By: Atratzu




Achievements: There are no steam achievements for Medieval II: Total War. There are historical battles that you can try your hand at, and in my opinion winning a historical battle that is usually lost, is a huge achievement.Price: Medieval II: Total war is priced at $19.99, most strategy games eat up time like it's nobodies business, I personally like to spend an hour for every dollar I spend and Medieval II: Total War will do just that, and then some.(Personal note: I do feel the need to thank the person who bought Medieval II: Total war for me as a gift many years ago. Thanks Golag, maybe someday I'll finally beat you in it.)Conclusion: Story: Emphasis on Historical facts and events (Very cool). Gameplay: Difficult to learn if you haven't played any other Total War games. Achievements: None, however there is no lack in difficulty. Price: Fair, almost all strategy games are worth their weight in game hours played.I recommend this game to Gamers who enjoy either History and/or strategy games. Generally it takes a fair amount of time to learn how a strategy game works, after you learn the mechanics then the game goes faster and it's very easy to get sucked into it.


Zoom up to the combat - Uploaded for the review 
A Screenshot of Medieval II: Total War
By: Atratzu




DLCHere's the URL to see my review for  Medieval II: Total War Kingdoms------Edits and updates------Edit/Update September 22, 2015:DLC review link added.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												Medieval II: Total War Positives:+ Nice music soundtrack which fits the Medieval theme of the game.+ Great unit variety, with swordsmen, spearmen, archers, cavalry and siege engines like trebuchets and catapults available to use.+ Many buildings to construct in your towns or castles, such as farms, roads, churches, leather tanneries and so on, each providing different benefits to your kingdom. + Dated graphics but they are still acceptable. Units like templar knights are quite colourful.+ A really cool religious system. Catholic countries in Europe have a reputation among the Pope which can be improved through completing religious missions or building churches. The higher your reputation the more sway you have with the holy leader, so you can order crusades in Muslim lands for honour and glory. If you play as an Islamic faction, you can order jihads lol.+ Decent map size extending across Europe and the Middle East.+ Expansion packs are huge and offer even more gameplay. + Command thousands of troops on screen at once in epic battles.+ Nice mix of agents on the campaign map, each with different purposes. Priests can convert regions to your religion and denounce witches or heretics, but if they are unsuccessful, could turn to a life of heresy themselves. Assassins are another key unit, skilled in the art of killing enemy generals or family members. Then there's merchants, which can capitalise on trade goods across the world map and send the profits back to your kingdom, but foreign merchants may try to drive you out of business! Diplomats are fairly self explanatory and royal princesses can visit other kingdoms to find a husband, while also acting as a diplomat too. + Hundreds of hours of gameplay here.Negatives:- Unit animations on the battlefield aren't very good. They're difficult to see and not that interesting. Later installments of the Total War series improved this. - Diplomacy is virtually useless, allies are unreliable and will attack for literally no reason, your relationship with them does not impact the likelihood of whether they will attack you. This is a major problem with the game, mods don't seem to fix anything (I've tried multiple ones.) - This game has constant warfare due to the broken diplomacy system. You never do get a break from conquering other kingdoms. Anyone who has played a total war game before knows that it can be quite overwhelming, tiresome and boring fighting turn after turn. It's nice to build your empire in peace sometimes. You don't really get that opportunity in Medieval II: Total War.- Overpowered Mongol hordes that appear during the late-game can be very irritating. For some unknown reason, Creative Assembly (the developers) like to throw a curve ball at the players in almost every single total war title they release. Total War: Shogun 2 had realm divide, where every Japanese faction declared war on you after you became too powerful, Total War: Rome II had civil wars, where massive armies spawn in your territory to take over. Medieval II: Total War has....the Mongols. All I can say is good luck and be prepared for when they arrive.Overall Score: 8/10Even though Medieval II: Total War is an old game which struggles with diplomacy and realism, it has a lot of fun features and micro-management which the more modern total war games seem to neglect. The use of priests to remove witches and heretics, the inquisition trialling your family's characters for blasphemy, the crusades, merchants who fight over resources  - this is all good, interesting gameplay on top of the real time battles. It's an excellent if not exhausting game, due to the AI's constant affinity for wanting to attack you.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												Pretty much like Civilization 4/5, only instead of some goofy animation of one dude/mechanical killing another, you get taken down to a map and engage in RTS action. You can compose armies of many unit types of the time period, and each one has an information card telling you about that unit and a description of their historical use. You can play as 5-ish factions initially, though you can unlock more.Just like Civ4/5, while on the overmap you can upgrade cities/castles and engage in trade/sabotage/war/diplomacy with other nations, only you can't build new cities, only take over others, though you can repurpose them to Towns(Money Makers) or make them into a Castle(Troop Maker), though both can make money or troops, their respective ones do it better.For those who have played Rome: Total War, Medieval is extremely similar, except during a different time period. There are improvements, such as improvements and supporting modern resolutions without mods.Speaking of mods. there are two very good ones, called "The Elder Scrolls: Total War", which let's you play in the Elder Scrolls world with all their empires and factions. And also "The Third Age: Total War", which let's you play in The Lord of the Rings world, in GREAT detail, and is rated one of the best mods for Medieval II: Total War, and is currently(March 5th, 2015) ranked #1 on ModDB.I greatly recommend this to any Total War or RTS fan.

Posted: March 24, 2015
												Even 9 years later, Medieval II Total War is still the best strategy game out there.  A huge amount of different factions and hundreds of different units means that each faction will have their own battlefield strategy.  On top of that, little details like the weather and elevation can come into play, not to mention how tired your own units are.  Despite all that complexity, the user interface is very simple and straightforward-even a novice can master the game's mechanics in as little as an hour of gameplay.  And if you somehow manage to exhaust the main campaign, the modding world has kept this game very much alive, with new mods always in the pipeline.

												After putting several thousand hours of time in to retail disc copy of M2TW, and having played all the other TW games, this is the best of the TW series when modded with Third age or Stainless Steel (available here http://www.twcenter.net/forums/forumdisplay.php?556-Kingdoms-Hosted-Modifications ).  Many of the other mods available for M2 are really good warhammer, EB2, Last Kingdom are worth trying out. (admittedly Shogun 2 is the best vanilla TW game)M2 has weight to its combat, that is lacking in the more frantic, less unit based style of R2 and Attila.  M2 has family tree integrated into the dynamics kingdom management, which is much reduced in later TW games, in M2 I care about family and generals in a way that I never do in subsequent.  With Third age mod the graphics are pretty close to as good as you'll get in later TW games (I run a Titan card so max out all settings in all TW games).M2 demonstrates why modding makes PC gaming the master race.

												Another game from the Total War game series and another hours spent conquering the map. This time we have the opportunity to dominate medieval europe and the surrounding area. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												Ignore the low play time... hundreds of hours have been amassed on a retail copy.Medieval II is, quite simply, one of the finest games I have ever played. It's the game that got me back into strategy games after a long hiatus, and that introduced me to what is now one of my favorite game series ever.But will you like it?Well, let's start from the beginning.Medieval II is a combination turn-based and real-time tactics strategy game that takes place in Europe, North Africa, and the Middle East during the Middle Ages. You can play as one of 17 different factions in the campaign mode (plus four others in skirmishes) that have a wide variety of playing styles, strengths, and weaknesses. As 450 years go by, the Old World is thrown into chaos- or Total War, as the narrator would say- as it endures Crusades and Jihads, rebellion and betrayal, infighting among the Christian nations, two monstrous hordes from the East, and that terrible calamity known as the Black Death, all while the slow wheel of time turns and technology continues to advance from the simple spear to the crossbow to the terrible might of gunpowder. The Kingdoms expansion essentially adds four entirely new games, with campaigns in more localized areas of the normal TW map with over a dozen new factions to play from, in scenarios that all present very different challenges.You will spend half of your time on the grand campaign map, a sort of political overworld where you manage the large affairs of your empire and move about your units. Here is where alliances are made and broken, provinces are developed, units are recruited, money is managed, and the dark tasks of espionage and assassination are undertaken. While a battle might change the course of a war, this is where you make sure that you have every chance of winning it in the first place.But most people play Total War for the battles. With the capacity to have thousands of units on the field at any given time, they're as much spectacle as strategy, as the ordered chaos of the battlefield threatens to overwhelm even the greatest captains. With a rich unit roster and a wide array of special abilities, your armies will be versatile and able to employ any number of tactics, from slowly whittling enemy numbers down with a stream of arrow fire to forming a defensive circle to protect your captain to employing a devastating hammer and anvil strike with your cavalry to launching diseased cow carcasses at their generals. Morale, terrain, weather, and energy levels all play important roles in how well your soldiers will be able to fight, and how well you will be able to govern the events of the battle.While there are some common strategies that can be undertaken for any nation or situation, no two campaigns or battles are the same, as the game can and will throw out surprises for you that you'll have to think quickly about to overcome. You may think you're doing well as France, fighting off England and preparing to make an invasion of the isles, when suddenly those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s in Portugal declare war on you and blockade all of your provinces, forcing you to stretch yourself out along two fronts. And while you may be able to overcome this obstacle, His Holiness the Pope probably won't take kindly to your conquests against your Catholic brethren, and may excommunicate you. All eventualities need to be prepared for in Total War if you want to survive.While this game is nearly a decade old, it still has a sizable and dedicated community of players to turn to if you want to fight a battle, try out a mod, or just get some friendly advice on how to deal with the Timurids. And as one of the easiest TW games to modify, it also has one of the best mod communities you'll be able to find, with an active base of players uploading and supporting their mods to this day. I highly recommend Stainless Steel, an expanded version of the base game with more provinces, factions, and units, and better AI, and also Third Age, a total conversion mod for Lord of the Rings that in my humble opinion is arguably the best TW game ever created, despite being a mod. If those two don't suit you, I'm sure you can find others that will.As for performance, the game still runs fine almost a decade after release, and still looks great. I can start a battle with 5,000 troops on the field and have little to no lag on my less than stellar computer. The score is also one of the finest I've had the pleasure of listening to in any game, and fits it very well.So, what are you waiting for? Go get the game! Europe won't conquer itself!

content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												Pretty much like Civilization 4/5, only instead of some goofy animation of one dude/mechanical killing another, you get taken down to a map and engage in RTS action. You can compose armies of many unit types of the time period, and each one has an information card telling you about that unit and a description of their historical use. You can play as 5-ish factions initially, though you can unlock more.Just like Civ4/5, while on the overmap you can upgrade cities/castles and engage in trade/sabotage/war/diplomacy with other nations, only you can't build new cities, only take over others, though you can repurpose them to Towns(Money Makers) or make them into a Castle(Troop Maker), though both can make money or troops, their respective ones do it better.For those who have played Rome: Total War, Medieval is extremely similar, except during a different time period. There are improvements, such as improvements and supporting modern resolutions without mods.Speaking of mods. there are two very good ones, called "The Elder Scrolls: Total War", which let's you play in the Elder Scrolls world with all their empires and factions. And also "The Third Age: Total War", which let's you play in The Lord of the Rings world, in GREAT detail, and is rated one of the best mods for Medieval II: Total War, and is currently(March 5th, 2015) ranked #1 on ModDB.I greatly recommend this to any Total War or RTS fan.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
												Don't be fooled by my hours, I've played for much much longer offline. In my first campagin as England, I ended up losing, but I didn't care, I had a blast with the battles, politics and everything else. I've had so many different adventures and scenarios, from a French invasion of England, culminating in a fatal last stand across the River Tent outside Nottingham, to a battle between my Spansh Musketeers, Conquistadors and Sword and buckler men against a massive Aztec army, ending with a mass route of the Aztec army after my cavalry charged down the side of a hill, Lord of the Rings style, into the Aztec's flank. And this was basically before I tried the mods. Stainless Steel adds a bigger map, more factions, more units, and tons more content, adding even MORE adventures and scenarios. How about a Russian conquest of Eastern Europe and Asia Minor circa 13th century, with a medival NATO of England, France, Denmark and Germany allyign to stop you? I've done it, and still haven't finished it yet. Rebuilding the Roman Empire with the Byzantine Empire? Was easy at first, until the Mongols showed up. I've got so many campaigns to get back to and start, I don't see myself ever deleting this game off my machine if I need space, or even out of boredom. If anyone offers you this game, it's cheap, or you're just thinking "Looks pretty cool", pick it up. You will not regret it. This is easily one of, if not the greatest, strategy games I've ever played in my life. Just one word of advice; prepare for the Mongol inavsion before hand, or you're going to have a BAAAD time :)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Following up the highly popular Rome, Medieval II is, perhaps not surprisingly, very similar to its immediate predecessor. Anyone who has played Rome can look at Medieval II and see essentially the same gameplay with a few added bits. Thankfully those added bits improve the core game enough that Medieval II stands on its own, managing to escape Rome's shadow... a bit.There are some silly issues that are often found in TW games: The AI is bad. Bad in the "I am suicidal with my generals" sort of way. At least they can actually fight battles competently enough, since this series has always (until Fall of the Samurai, perhaps) been at its best with swords, bows, and catapults. You do get the beginnings of the "pike and shot" era in this game, but really the focus is on the lovely middle ages.As for the good bits, the Grand Campaign is, well, grand. A big map that can be made even bigger with mods, plenty of events that sometimes herald the arrival of new factions (ze Mongols!), and lots of fun with religion and crusades and burning  heretics. You have to unlock the rest of the factions by playing one of the starter nations (England, France, Spain, etc), but once you do there is plenty of replay value to be found here. And, of course, there are mods. Plenty for Medieval II, though the real gems require its Kingdoms expansion. So, if you want to lead big armies in the middle ages and charge around Europe setting stuff on fire, this game is plenty good for that. It's similarity to Rome might lead some players to get bored a little faster, but they can just get mods and play something fresh. Also get the Kingdoms expansion so you can delve into some of the best mods ever made.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												     This, in my opinion, is THE best total war game that they've made. And in addition, it is my favorite strategy game. The only RTS game that I can think of that is better, would be C&C Generals, but EA never made a second one!!!Back to medieval, for a bit of an outdated game it still looks amazing, and it runs flawlessly, highest settings, even on my computer which only has 2 lousy GB of RAM. They campaign is fun, and it feels more in-depth, and more "wholesome" than the newer TW games like ROME 2. Just little things that you'll notice throughout the game that'll  make it just SO much more fun. The kingdoms expansion is even better!!! 90% of my logged game time is just the brittania campaign. I can't get enough of this game, I spend hours on end glued to my screen witnessing my armies conquer, and my "light" Ostmen slaughtering heavy Scottish Nobleman like they were pigs. And unlike ROME 2 where in melee combat, infantry just gets into a giant clusterf@#k and it takes forever for one side to win, melee combat in this game is so much better, each soldier in a unit has their own little fight and they're pals may jump in and help em out with a quick axe-to-the-head. I can go on and on about how amazing this game is, but then you'd be reading this for hours. Just buy the game. And see how amazing it is for yourselves. And you wont regret it. 10/10 one of the greatest games EVER made.P.S. - ELEPHANTS WITH CANNONS. end of story...

content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												  So this was my first Total war game. I highly recommend it to people who enjoy the RTS genre of games. It is a perfect blend of Turn based strategy and risk style of game in the grand campaign. But with the cool feature where you command Thousands of troops and you decide the outcome of each battle. The tricky bit for me to learn was the economy and how trade works and how to manage it the best, but with a little patience and a bit of cunning even you can slaughter the helpless annoying pope who excomunnicates you when you pet a kitten that is homeless. My favorite nation was the Holy Roman Empire (one of the five startering nations to pick from) I suggest new players play as ether as England or France they are the simplest nations. To start with, KEEP in mind every little action you do as a christian country will  affect the pope. So ether slaughter the old guy or give him boxes and boxes of chocolates and stay away from his anger. This is my first review I hope it was a decent one.

content:
Posted: March 25, 2016
												After putting several thousand hours of time in to retail disc copy of M2TW, and having played all the other TW games, this is the best of the TW series when modded with Third age or Stainless Steel (available here http://www.twcenter.net/forums/forumdisplay.php?556-Kingdoms-Hosted-Modifications ).  Many of the other mods available for M2 are really good warhammer, EB2, Last Kingdom are worth trying out. (admittedly Shogun 2 is the best vanilla TW game)M2 has weight to its combat, that is lacking in the more frantic, less unit based style of R2 and Attila.  M2 has family tree integrated into the dynamics kingdom management, which is much reduced in later TW games, in M2 I care about family and generals in a way that I never do in subsequent.  With Third age mod the graphics are pretty close to as good as you'll get in later TW games (I run a Titan card so max out all settings in all TW games).M2 demonstrates why modding makes PC gaming the master race.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												Where have you been all my life?I purchased Medieval II: Total War when it was on a sale a while back, but never 'opened' it. I bought it because I remember seeing a friend playing it when it first came out, and two things stuck in my mind:1. WOW! 8 GB on my hard drive?! That's too much space!2. Man, these battles are huge! And you have to manage the governance? That's insane!I'm a big fan of the Age of Empires series, so I was very used to a simpler, more combat-focused game series. M2TW's size (legitimately, that wasn't just a joke) as well as the amount of managing you needed to do looked intimidating to me, so I never tried it.How wrong I was.This game is absolutely glorious. Managing your nation, commanding your armies, working through all the inner workings of medieval society: this game found a way to make it work together. Here's an example: In the short British campaign, you have to conquer both Scotland and France. Scotland has few allies, so they weren't difficult to invade. However, France was a whole different story. France was not only allied with many of my neighbours (The Holy Roman Empire and Milan), but they were highly regarded by the Pope of the Catholic Church. If I tried to invade France, not only did I have to also fight against their allies, but I risked becoming excommunicated. I went for the risk, becoming both excommunicated and enemies to nearly all Catholic nations, and that made my French conquest significantly harder. I had to stop playing that campaign because, while my nation was the strongest, my borders were constantly under attack every turn, and I'd rather start a new campaign and learn from my mistakes.Albeit still a computer program and not reality, Medieval II feels like the closest thing to a simulator of Medieval combat. It's almost as if they intended to create a game series and engine to emulate that!I have not checked out the other Total War games, but I am going to once I'm done with my campaign on this one. So, in conclusion, if you're a fan of Strategy games and haven't tried these games, go for it! It has quickly become one of my favourite games, and I'd recommend it to anyone who's looking for something new.Or old. I'm really behind the curve on this.

												This is the last pre-warscape CA Total War game, and really the last that could be successfully modded extensively.  This latter piece of the puzzle matters because some of the community dating back to when the game originallly released went to a lot of trouble to make mods, such as Stainless Steel and the total conversion for Lord of the Rings: Third Age.For me, the charm of Medieval 2 though is really centered around the game itself, the time period is so well suited for the style of game play that CA makes with the turn based stragegy map combined with the real time tactical battles that the result is just endless amounts of fantastic game play.This and Shogun 2 are for me the two best games CA has ever created.  Thumbs way up.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												I played this on CD to the point that the disk stopped working. I don't have an hour total, but I can assure you I spent a good two or three years putting about as much time into this as I did my full time job.Probably the last really well thought out Total War game, and one of the least buggy. There is no stupidly awkward city management system (Empire), most of the factions are reasonably well balanced (with the exception of the Italian States, who are crushingly overpowered in a player's hands - still better than pretty well all the other total war games out there), and things move at a pace that doesn't feel to relaxed or too rushed (shogun, napolean).It's not a masterpiece by any means, but now that I revisit them, I don't think any of the Total War games really are. It is a pretty fun game though, and certainly worth getting if you've are looking to get into the series.Edit: When I say "the least buggy", I'm just refering to the Steam versions. Rome:TW on CD, from like a decade ago, remains stable as a ♥♥♥♥ing rock resting on the surface of a giant steel cube with the gravitational pull of a black hole. There is also a 6 billion ton weight sitting on top of the rock. I've been told the Steam version doesn't work that well, but haven't had to try it despite having lost my Rome CD recently, because Rome is from an era where devs depended on human decency and CD codes as DRM.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												I love this game. It looks a bit dated now after some of the more recent Total War series, but this is an extremely interesting time period for warfare. The game suffers a bit on the campaign map by being a bit too ambitious; there are a bit too many merchants, priests, spies, assassins, princesses to move around. But the real-time battles can be simply glorious, and the historical accuracy make the experience ultimately fulfilling. If you're patient, the Grand Campaign can be a true strategic adventure.  Be warned! This game has a third-party launcher that has a bug and it may need to be killed from the task-manager under "processes" most times that you play. There may also be a problem with the Kingdoms DLC, so check the forums first! Don't be put off, though, this game is pretty damn good!

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												This is probably my second favorite Total War game after Shogun 2. The middle age setting is amazing and the graphics hold up pretty well for how old it is now. Nothing beats slaughtering thousands of enemies using English Longbowmen or Venetian Heavy infantry, the battles are just so large and require knowledge of tactics. One thing that anoys me is the enemy campaign AI and the diplomacy, the AI doesn't raise balanced armies and is usually just lots of the same unit type. The differences that set apart all of the factions really make a difference when playing, for exapmle using the English you want to be building armies that are focused on using Longbowmen but other factions don't have that option. I have had hundreds of hours fun on this game over the years and i'm sure I will be playing it for many more years!

content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												Medievil 2 is one of the best games i have ever played.Why?The game's combat is a little easy (Use alot cavilry and you'll win alot of engagments), but the game is good. I can't say the game is incredibly hard to play, because it isn't, it's easy to learn. But the game is hard to master...The base game is a little broken, for instance im playing as the Holy Roman Empire right now and i'm being invaded on all sides. I got poland, venice, millan, and france all attacking me, yet im alive because i win the battles (but my economy is taking a toll for the worse).But if this is bugging you, you want a total war game where it's more realistic? Get the 'Stainless Steal' mod that improves the core game to be more realistic and hard. Essentially making the game a tonne better.but i'm not really all for that, but i do lord of the rings. The lord of the rings mod allowed me to  take back moria and kill balrog as the drawves, there were so many dead drawves... 	 but it also allowed me to get a good feel of lotr as it has everything that the books have and the movies missed (though based on the movies visually). But alot of people want to get the new total war warhammer game, but you probably have heard (or you haven't whatever) of the "Rage of the dark gods" which is so indepth that you have chaos drawves, orks, drawves, vampire counts, empire, all the different chaos gods, kislev, beast men and more. So you have a free mods that's probably more indepth than the new game comming out.So in the end, if you want a medievil tw game then get it, you want a realistic tw medevil game then get Stainless steal mod when you get it, you want a lord of the rings strategy game then get this and the mod, you want to get total war warhammer then get it.Do mind that the mods require kingdoms, which is a dlc that adds (i think) 5 new campaigns that are each build on the base game (they include NEW campaigns, not just factions like in rome2/atilla)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												A great game that I have poured over 100s of hours into. There are plenty of options as to how you want to raise your kingdom to be the greatest of all time. WIll your king be an honourable man, one who releases all his prisoners? Or a dreadful man, whose subjects follow him not out of loyalty, but fear? Will you cement a lasting alliance with the kingdom on your borders by marrying off your young princess to their prince, or will you slaughter them, burning their towns and villages and killing all their lords? Although the game lacks extreme political intrigue, there is enough there to keep you playing for a loong time. You can use covert ops (such as assassins and spies) to eliminate the lords and ladies of the enemy, weakening their forces before you ride in, killing everyone. There is so much to do in this game, and the RTS combat is fantastic. True strategy is necessary to win on the field of battle. A competent commander will triumph over the greatest of odds if his enemies blunder about like fools. There is also a great deal of diversity throughout the units for each faction. And, despite how old this game is, I assure you, the multiplayer community is very much alive and well. A must buy for TW fans, and strategy fans in general.

												Such a great game. Well worth the money, well worth getting the Kingdoms DLC with it, just adds more to do really. Honestly, I would say this is the best out of the Total War series. I like the feature of being able to put units under AI command, have the AI take control of an army during a battle, though the AI is bad, it is still a handy feature if you want to witness giant battles. It is a shame they didn't include it in the later games. I love being able to buid up armies and attack huge castles with mighty siege equipment, it is just awesome.The game lacks some things, but it is old. There can be stressful moments, where the AI acts like a complete idiot, you cannot position your troops where you want to position them, some slight issues, but the game is still awesome and playable. Has some great mods out there for it, so you can go and experience them too.Highly recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												I am going to compare this game to Rome: Total War, an older entry of the series.Improvements I instantly notice:Naval combat feels very rewarding! It is still autocalculated, but 2 ships will go up against 1 and you will probably win. 6 ship can go against 5 enemy ships, and you might just win a heroic victory with 0 losses! Instead of the SPQR for Roman Factions, you have a Pope for the many different Catholic factions! This is a good addition in my opinion, as now more factions feel fleshed out. Graphics are better here and there, but the way my settings are, I don't really notice major differences. Not that the graphics hold anything back!Pre-battle speeches feel nice and Medieval-like! Though they are slightly repetitive, they're still a joy to listen to. There is no balance issues that I can see, but the Byzantines/Turks and the Holy Roman Empire seem to have it easier early on when they're played by AI. Crusades are a nice new addition as well! For the most part, the Campaign map feels the same. However, a key difference is that you can swap a settlement between being a Castle or a Town. Castles offer military power, whilst Towns offer economic power. The choice is yours!Agent system feels a lot more immersive.There are tons of cinematics! It feels like an achievement just to have a Spy take a look at a few stray enemy units.MP is still kicking, but Rome 1's MP is also alive. It is also only worth $20, with a very cheap DLC! That is a complete steal for a game like this. That said, Rome 1 is cheaper.Probably one of the best things this game has is the fact that the map is more immersive! There was historical events in Rome 1 like volcanoes and floods, but now you can witness the spawn of the Mongols, or contact Aztecs when you have been confined to Europe all this time!10/10Would marry off my daughters to Genghis Khan again!

content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												Wanna know how I got these hours? I'll sum it up in one word. Mods. Without all the beautiful mods, that have been created by an amazing community, I wouldn't have loved this game as much as I currently do. Without the mods it is still an amazing game. One of the best, if not the best current Total War. Amazing cavalry charge, beautiful arrow stagger, and even those awesome armor upgrades. If you want to start playing Total War then I urge you to buy this game. Does it have it's cons? Yes, yes it does. There are many bugs and glitches. I've encountered a few crashes, and since this an older game be ready for lag if you try to have the graphics and unit sizes to the highest setting. There have been a couple bugs that annoy the ever-living crap outta me. Such as during Sieges, you try to run your archers off the walls but half of them stay there. If you try to set them up behind the wall they were just on, prepare for stupid unit Ai. They form up against the buildings or something stupid like that.Even with the oldness, the bugs, the crashes. I still give this game a 10/10 because of the amazing mods it has.Third Age: Total WarElder Scrolls: Total WarCall of Warhammer: Total WarPlanetary War: Total WarJust to name the four I use. So buy it, buy Kingdoms with it. Then go on to download all the mods. If you don't then get excommunicated scrub.THIS MOD FOR TEST OF TIME NOMINATION!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												I grew up with this game, form the age of seven. I still play it regulary. I have downloaded tenfolds of mods. This is the pinnacle of Total War. The raw brutality, the strategy adn the epic fights. And the mods. The oh so glorious mods. It says have 544 hrs on record, but with the cd version and the Kingdoms expansion (which got removed after the steam update), I must have played it for several thousand hours. The DLC is also great. It is what a DLC is supposed to be. You have the base game, fully fleshed out (Unlike Warhammer etc), and then it adds  not one, not two, but FOUR whole new maps, with new factions and units to play as, for really cheap. That is what a DLC should be. The mods are also fantastic, ranging from Warhammer, LOTR, Italy in the 16th century, Japan, even the whole world. Even crazy mods, such as Planetwar, with klingons, aliens v Predator, Shrek and Romans in one group. There is so much to say about the mods, I could spend hours writing about them.While to community might not be the largest, it's certianly one of the best I've seen. Everyone is friendly, and gives advise. There might be some salt here and there, but that's the exeption that confirms the rule.If you are interested in strategy, buy this. If you like massive battles, buy this. If you like mods, buy this. If you have a little extra money to spend, this is the game to buy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9
												This is honestly my favorite game currently, the engine is better than... others *cough* *cough* Empire. It is a classic no doubt. It is in the medieval time period which is one of my favorites. Also the game has some of the greatest mods such as Third Age and Stainless Steel. Another bonus is the campaign, it has so many balancing aspects such as the preventation of elite unit spaming. Another bonus is the factions, their is a big variety and the fact that England has their longbows, France has their variety of good cavalry, well not the Lancers or Gendarms. The Polish have their good cheep cavalry and Egypt has their naphatunes, but so does turkey and others that I can not name off the top of my head. Anyways, the main downfall I find in this game is the fact that it is old, so the graphics aren't perfect and the game can't run huge battles, regardless you PC. To sum it up, it is rediculasly fun and deserves all the praise it gets. I managed to put around 100 hours into this game after the first month of having it. I HEAVLY recomend this game to anyone into RTS TS and the medieval genre. Sorry for my spelling by the way:)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												This was my latest game in Medieval 2: Total WarI started playing as HRE (Holy Roman Empire). Things was peaceful, all I did was conquering nearby barbarian cities, so did all my other neighbors. Suddenly Venice attacks me. Some few battles and the lines are at a stalemate. Milan attacks me and they ally with Venice. Milan is excommunicated by the Pope for attacking me. Pope declares crusade against Cairo. My heir joins a crusade and marches down through East Europe, through the holy lands and after nearly 10 years he arrives and conquers Cairo just before Poland reaches there. Pope loves me. I then conquer Alexandria so that I can create a Mediterranean fleet so that my Heir Henry the Crusader can come back to his father before he dies of old age. Pope dies of old age. Archbishop of Milan is voted as Pope. Milan is not anymore excommunicated and is now loved by Pope. Papal state declares war against me and allies with Milan and Venice. My emperor dies in Bologna. Bologna is just after conquered by Papal state with the Pope himself in the army. Suddenly there is no secure land to land my new Emperor Henry the Crusader. Pope starts a new crusade. Again it is against Cairo, only this time it's under my control... 2 years after a Jihad is started, also against Cairo. My hatred for the newly vided Pope is great. I use more years and create an even bigger fleet so that the venetian fleet can't outmatch it. I then send Emperor Henry the Crusader and his crusader army (the ones that conquered Cairo and Alexandria). Because of little troops after my emperor left Alexandria, it rebels and all surviving troops are sent to Cairo. Some years after Emperor Henry the Crusader lands outside of Rome and attacks the Pope himself. Emperor Henry the Crusader kills the Pope with his crusader army. 11/10 Best game ever <3

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												One of the finest RTS games I have played and probably my only real favourite in the Total War series.  Within this game you start off as one of the monarchies of the medieval era, England, France, Spain etc, inhabiting the West with the Turks, Egyptians, the Moors etc controlling most of the Eastern regions.  And I use control loosely, for this game is about constant strife, border control and damning your so called allies to your own religious hierarchies.  The gameplay itself is split into two halves.  One half is the typical RTS strategic combat, where two armies with varied units, face each other on the battlefield to determine a victor!  In this part of the game, there is a Rock Paper Scissors style of strategy, with Spears besting Knights, Knights besting Archers and Archers besting Spears, though as your own technology expands and your coffers grow larger, more diverse units will be available to you.The AI can be a little stupid at times, often forgetting your commands or taking an insanely longer route than it needs to travel to reach it's destination.  So some micromanagement is needed there.  The second part of the gameplay is entirely Turn-Based.  You begin with a selection of territories relevant to your faction's Monarchy, you also have your own Royal Family who each have their own needs and quirks which affect your overall strategy.  And in this phase of the game you'll be charged with building your resources, exploring the world, and interacting with your neighbours.  Honestly I find this part of the game to actually be rather interesting, it's always fun to approach your neighbours with peace offerings and treaties, only to plan treachery for when the time is right.  And there are numerous and inventive ways you can attempt to accomplish this through, in a very Game of Thrones style of diplomacy if you're familiar with the subject matter.I found this to be the better of the Total War series.  Others will have their preferences to Rome, Shogun or maybe even the Napoleonic Wars, but if you have any doubts of either, just do your research.  I hope my review will help contribute to that.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
												I am officially addicted to this game. Like the Football Manager series before me playing this game, it is very addictive and so much fun. Prior to purchasing Medieval II: Total War, I had only heard of the 'Rome II' edition which is the latest game in the series and the reviews didn't look too good for it, so I chose this, which I find a fascinating period in history. Anybody who is thinking of playing this game for the first time, give a couple of hours on a new campaign and once you get your head around how to play it, Medieval II: Total War is crackin' - Graphics are good, slightly dated, but the graphics aren't the sole reason you'd buy this game. I also bought the extensoin pack [Kingdoms] which allows you to pick from another variety of factions [eg Jerusalem/Crusades etc] - I can't praise the game enough. I love it and if you're looking for a great strategy game, steeped in history, this is for you. Enjoy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 2, 2013
												My personal favorite in the Total War series. Medieval 2 gains a lot by being set in a time and place that is more or less easily recognizable to westerners. Assuming you start the game as the default English or French, you'll be mostly battling accross Europe with late game forays into northern Africa, western Russia, and the Middle East. Your units will, for the most part, also be familiar and easily understood. Even a casual student of medieval European history will understand why charging a spear wall with calvary is a bad idea, or why you don't use tight formations to advance into arrow or catapult fire. The game's medieval atmosphere is further boosted by a provocative musical score, accurate sound effects, and nation-themed voice dialogue. Gamplay in Medieval II, like any Total War game, is dividied between the strategic global campaign map and tactical maps where battles are played out. The strategic gameplay is solid, and players will be required to juggle tax income, religion, unrest, noble desires, and public health with the logistical demands of supporting your armies between battles. While the game lacks the research tech tree introduced in Empire, technology pacing is present through city building. As you build and upgrade your stables, archery ranges, and barracks you'll gain access to new troop types while smithies, jousting fields, and swordsmen guilds will enhance the equipment and quality of troops. Tactical gameplay is fantastic with players having strong control over formations, positioning, and abilities. Complexity is added in with morale and stamina mechanics, both of which are easily understood and implemented in a way that makes sense. The few faults that do exist in the tactical gameplay only emerge when directly comparing the game to more recent Total Wars, like Shogun 2 or Rome 2. Combat and unit cohesion in Medieval 2 can feel more rigid and unresponsive than its successors, but never enough to seriously impede gameplay.
