content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												Medieval II is an magnificent game that will steal hours if not days from your life.  Important note though,  this game has a mix between  Turn-Based kingdom management  and  Real Time battles  so  if you don't like TBS or RTS games i don't think MII is for you.  Vanilla MII is a great game, but i personally suggest that you download either the StainlessSteel or the DarthMod mod conversions which change several game parameter and drastically increases the difficulty and adds tons of new content to the game. Diplomacy is pretty light but it is a forgivable feature due to this being a  Total War  game and the whole point is to wage war and conquer everything in sight. Vanilla AI pathfinding i horrible in sieges, but there are some mods that can fix it, although not fully. In conclusion, MII is a unforgettable game that is certainly worth the low price you pay for tons of hours of war and conquest.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												Wanna know how I got these hours? I'll sum it up in one word. Mods. Without all the beautiful mods, that have been created by an amazing community, I wouldn't have loved this game as much as I currently do. Without the mods it is still an amazing game. One of the best, if not the best current Total War. Amazing cavalry charge, beautiful arrow stagger, and even those awesome armor upgrades. If you want to start playing Total War then I urge you to buy this game. Does it have it's cons? Yes, yes it does. There are many bugs and glitches. I've encountered a few crashes, and since this an older game be ready for lag if you try to have the graphics and unit sizes to the highest setting. There have been a couple bugs that annoy the ever-living crap outta me. Such as during Sieges, you try to run your archers off the walls but half of them stay there. If you try to set them up behind the wall they were just on, prepare for stupid unit Ai. They form up against the buildings or something stupid like that.Even with the oldness, the bugs, the crashes. I still give this game a 10/10 because of the amazing mods it has.Third Age: Total WarElder Scrolls: Total WarCall of Warhammer: Total WarPlanetary War: Total WarJust to name the four I use. So buy it, buy Kingdoms with it. Then go on to download all the mods. If you don't then get excommunicated scrub.THIS MOD FOR TEST OF TIME NOMINATION!

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												I love this game. It looks a bit dated now after some of the more recent Total War series, but this is an extremely interesting time period for warfare. The game suffers a bit on the campaign map by being a bit too ambitious; there are a bit too many merchants, priests, spies, assassins, princesses to move around. But the real-time battles can be simply glorious, and the historical accuracy make the experience ultimately fulfilling. If you're patient, the Grand Campaign can be a true strategic adventure.  Be warned! This game has a third-party launcher that has a bug and it may need to be killed from the task-manager under "processes" most times that you play. There may also be a problem with the Kingdoms DLC, so check the forums first! Don't be put off, though, this game is pretty damn good!

content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
												Out of all the Total War games, I've liked Medieval II the most, mainly since it has enough mechanics to the gameplay without adding too much complexity that you end up using in the end.  As an example of this, I found the merchant mechanics pointless in Empire Total War when you're going for a conquest victory.  There's also a lot of content here with the new world discovery, and the Kingdoms expansion, which do more than just change the map around, especially with the new world scenario.  The downside is the AI can be very stupid at times, like when you're being sieged you can sallly out, and the enemy will for the most part stand still until you're close.  So for instance, you can use a balista or archers to take them all out if you position them on the flanks of the sieging army and you won't take any casualities.Aside from that, a really good buy, especially if you can get it on sale.

Posted: March 20, 2016
												Medievil 2 is one of the best games i have ever played.Why?The game's combat is a little easy (Use alot cavilry and you'll win alot of engagments), but the game is good. I can't say the game is incredibly hard to play, because it isn't, it's easy to learn. But the game is hard to master...The base game is a little broken, for instance im playing as the Holy Roman Empire right now and i'm being invaded on all sides. I got poland, venice, millan, and france all attacking me, yet im alive because i win the battles (but my economy is taking a toll for the worse).But if this is bugging you, you want a total war game where it's more realistic? Get the 'Stainless Steal' mod that improves the core game to be more realistic and hard. Essentially making the game a tonne better.but i'm not really all for that, but i do lord of the rings. The lord of the rings mod allowed me to  take back moria and kill balrog as the drawves, there were so many dead drawves... 	 but it also allowed me to get a good feel of lotr as it has everything that the books have and the movies missed (though based on the movies visually). But alot of people want to get the new total war warhammer game, but you probably have heard (or you haven't whatever) of the "Rage of the dark gods" which is so indepth that you have chaos drawves, orks, drawves, vampire counts, empire, all the different chaos gods, kislev, beast men and more. So you have a free mods that's probably more indepth than the new game comming out.So in the end, if you want a medievil tw game then get it, you want a realistic tw medevil game then get Stainless steal mod when you get it, you want a lord of the rings strategy game then get this and the mod, you want to get total war warhammer then get it.Do mind that the mods require kingdoms, which is a dlc that adds (i think) 5 new campaigns that are each build on the base game (they include NEW campaigns, not just factions like in rome2/atilla)

content:
Posted: April 10, 2016
												  Played this game for over 400 hours and loved every minute. The base game was fantastic and offered a great mix of intellectual organization and also the opprotunity for roleplay elements, the world map being large enough to keep you satisfied with whichever nation you choose as it will always provide a challenge to turn that map one colour.  The DLC was also some of the best I've played in most likely any of the Total war Series. Each capturing a different period of medieval history while also providing a range of challenges. The America campaign being one of my favorites since it shifts the atmosphere of the game so radically.  Now as if the base game and DLC wasn't enough. the community has picked every piece of meat from the bone in terms of mods for the game which allow you to play as a lord of the Seven kingdoms of Westeros, the Uruks of Isengard or even just mods that increase realism and immersion.  This game has captured my attention for over 400 hours, and its been a solid experiance the entire time.9/10

content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
												I am officially addicted to this game. Like the Football Manager series before me playing this game, it is very addictive and so much fun. Prior to purchasing Medieval II: Total War, I had only heard of the 'Rome II' edition which is the latest game in the series and the reviews didn't look too good for it, so I chose this, which I find a fascinating period in history. Anybody who is thinking of playing this game for the first time, give a couple of hours on a new campaign and once you get your head around how to play it, Medieval II: Total War is crackin' - Graphics are good, slightly dated, but the graphics aren't the sole reason you'd buy this game. I also bought the extensoin pack [Kingdoms] which allows you to pick from another variety of factions [eg Jerusalem/Crusades etc] - I can't praise the game enough. I love it and if you're looking for a great strategy game, steeped in history, this is for you. Enjoy.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												This was my latest game in Medieval 2: Total WarI started playing as HRE (Holy Roman Empire). Things was peaceful, all I did was conquering nearby barbarian cities, so did all my other neighbors. Suddenly Venice attacks me. Some few battles and the lines are at a stalemate. Milan attacks me and they ally with Venice. Milan is excommunicated by the Pope for attacking me. Pope declares crusade against Cairo. My heir joins a crusade and marches down through East Europe, through the holy lands and after nearly 10 years he arrives and conquers Cairo just before Poland reaches there. Pope loves me. I then conquer Alexandria so that I can create a Mediterranean fleet so that my Heir Henry the Crusader can come back to his father before he dies of old age. Pope dies of old age. Archbishop of Milan is voted as Pope. Milan is not anymore excommunicated and is now loved by Pope. Papal state declares war against me and allies with Milan and Venice. My emperor dies in Bologna. Bologna is just after conquered by Papal state with the Pope himself in the army. Suddenly there is no secure land to land my new Emperor Henry the Crusader. Pope starts a new crusade. Again it is against Cairo, only this time it's under my control... 2 years after a Jihad is started, also against Cairo. My hatred for the newly vided Pope is great. I use more years and create an even bigger fleet so that the venetian fleet can't outmatch it. I then send Emperor Henry the Crusader and his crusader army (the ones that conquered Cairo and Alexandria). Because of little troops after my emperor left Alexandria, it rebels and all surviving troops are sent to Cairo. Some years after Emperor Henry the Crusader lands outside of Rome and attacks the Pope himself. Emperor Henry the Crusader kills the Pope with his crusader army. 11/10 Best game ever <3

												-Be Playing Medieval II:Total War as England, get an alliance with France, Spain and Poland/Germany-Brothels are keeping my morale in my cities somewhat steady after conquering all of Britain and Sweden despite constant Rebel armies appearing for no real reason (REBEL SCUM)-France keeps asking for money, politely tell them to go♥♥♥♥♥♥off and settle for giving them a part of Sweden.-France give me the seen..no contact for a few turns.-We team up upon getting attacked by Portugal and attack Rebel bases and Portugal together (Screw you Portugal and your infinite Navy)-Think to myself "France is okay after all"-France then turns around along with Spain and Poland and the new German Empire and declares on me.-Decide to not go down like a b!tch and lay siege to Paris, get kicked from the catholic church over and over again for defending myself.-After 90ish turns I have wiped out the Germans (dont know what the factions called), SEEMINGLY all of the French (Traitor Scum). Then Annihalate most of Venice, Spain, Sicily and Portugal as well as Russia but lucky for them i'm low on troops and funds at this point despite owning all of West Europe and a part of East Europe.-SUDDENLY, the Mongols invade. Due to my absolute war machine I have dismantled and crippled most of the AI's in Europe leaving a huge power vacuum.-7 turns after the Mongols showed up they have invaded Poland, Russia and anyone east/southeast of Italy asides from Egypt and Turkey have been destroyed.-10 turns after the Mongols showed up they have massacred my forces that were spread too thin.-Rush to get all my troops from France,England and North Italy to stop the onslaught.-SUDDENLY it turns out France had been hiding in North Africa all along and they send troops up via ships (Was too busy with the Mongols to even notice)-France proceeds to pretty much screw me up with cannons and I get tea bagged for a few more turns before turning off the Laptop and crying tears of anger as I see the French throwing baguettes at my dying ecosystem (RIP Britain and Ireland 02/01/16 - 06/01/16).10/10Would get fisted by France and the Mongols again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												Medieval 2: Total War is one of the best games from the Total War series. The game itself is really in-depth, and the strategy is so immersive and complex. Even the campaign map has hidden strategies for managing the diplomacy of your kingdom, which makes the seemingly uncalled for attacks from neighboring nations look a lot less random. The battlefields and units are designed very well and the whole game looks very polished. Battle strategies can be somewhat complex, but once you get the hang of them you will feel like a 5 star general. Not to mention the fact that you can even modify the game to play as the papal states, which has influence over most European factions. I haven't tried any big mods for this game yet, but I've heard about many of them, so it's nice to know that there are options out there in the unlikely event that I ever get bored with the main game. If you're looking to buy anything on Steam, this is a game you should seriously consider adding to your library. Happy warmongering!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												YES!!! This game is a most definite 4 thumbs up! If you love strategy and have always wanted to test your skills then here is the PERFECT game for you! There's so many campaigns and each one for each faction is differernt in its own way. Also, each faction has a few perks that none of the others have; for instamce: English, Longbowmen; French, Courageous Knights; HRE (Holy Roman Empire), has average everything; so on and so forth. There's so many different factions that if I wrote down all their strengths and weaknesses it would take me about an hour to do so! And even on the lowest graphics setting it still doesn't look half bad. It also has historical battles like Agincourt, Hastings, I think it has Stamford Bridge but not for sure. Please don't hesitate to buy it because of the price its well worth it! (in fact, i bought it for $5 while it was on sale :D) I hope to see you on guys!Please play this game guys you'd love it especially if you download the Kingdoms DLC whick isn't needed or anything but it adds a lot more campaigns to be played.Also, this game alerts you to events that are happening in the world (like the Black Plague or the Mongolian invasion). Thus forcing you to respond to the changes in your environment by either building more defensive structures and training more troops in one area or maneuvering soldiers to another position. I absolutely love this game it is one of my all-time favorites.

												Medieval II is an amazing spectacle and a fun game to play. Not only are thousands of hand-chosen soldiers fighting at your command, but cities rise and fall at your leisure based on war, diplomacy, sabotage, and assassination. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												Such a great game. Well worth the money, well worth getting the Kingdoms DLC with it, just adds more to do really. Honestly, I would say this is the best out of the Total War series. I like the feature of being able to put units under AI command, have the AI take control of an army during a battle, though the AI is bad, it is still a handy feature if you want to witness giant battles. It is a shame they didn't include it in the later games. I love being able to buid up armies and attack huge castles with mighty siege equipment, it is just awesome.The game lacks some things, but it is old. There can be stressful moments, where the AI acts like a complete idiot, you cannot position your troops where you want to position them, some slight issues, but the game is still awesome and playable. Has some great mods out there for it, so you can go and experience them too.Highly recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												Played this game since its release in 2006, bought a digital copy via steam when my old CD stopped working.You'll like this game if you like history. It certainly isn't "perfectly accurate" (is anything?), but it tries a lot harder than most games. At least, at the outset. The point of this series is to screw with history. I once played as the Almoravids of al-Andalus and crossed the Atlantic, converting the Americas to Islam. I once played as the Byzantine Empire and transplanted the entire dynasty to sub-Saharan Africa, watching as the rest of the world was eclipsed by the Mongol tide.The other great thing about this game is the mods. The best ones I know of are Third Age, Rage of the Dark Gods, and Hyrule. You can find one to suit almost any fancy. I just got done ravaging the Shire and Rivendell as Isengard.Seriously, pick up this game if you have $20 to spare. You won't be disappointed.

												If you have a short attention span or get frustrated really easy then this is NOT the game for you. However, when you get passed the learning curve its a really addictive game.  There are moments where it feels like it stutters, after computer moves for one. The camera controls i found really annoying to get used to, i keep using wasd when its numpad for movement but you can scroll with the mouse to an extent. Once your used to this its fine. There is no better feeling than crushing an army of 900 men when you only have 450 yourself.  This is one game i can see me poking me head back into for a while, there are many aspects to manage at once and i was never a fan of turn based strategy untill i took a gamble and brought it to see what this total war genre was all about.This is one game a recommend for a sunday afternoon when you have alot of time on your hands.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												Medieval 2 stands the test of time. I've been playing this game long before it was ever on my steam account (which I believe I added it on here 7 years ago? Could be wrong) but even to this day I find myself playing it for hours on end. The base game itself is excellent for casual playing. If you want to sit back and relax as the English and build up your settlements on the British Isles before sweeping through France, you can. If you wish to conquer the Easetern world as the Egyptians, you can. If you wish to unite Italy under one banner long before it ever was in the history books, you can.On top of this, the Kingdoms expansion allows for not only 4 more campaigns, but for an excellent modding community. Third Age: Total War is perhaps the greatest mod for any game I have ever witnessed and it accounts for over half the hours I've put into M2:TW.Could not reccomend this game enough, it's a must have for your Steam library.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												I've played Shogun TW, Medieval TW, Medieval 2 TW, Empire TW and Shogun 2 TW and this game by far is the best of them all. It's one of the best strategy games I've ever played. I'm speaking from a strictly SP POV though. The game is pretty old now but it still looks quite nice with the settings turned up.I've never been able to figure out diplomacy in this game so I always just end up making a lot of enemies and crushing them by brute force. I'm not sure if that's my play style or a flaw in the game's diplomacy system though.The AI is decently intelligent both on the campaign map and on the battlefield.I absolutely hate and despise naval battles in all TW games after this one. It's one of the main reasons I haven't been able to enjoy any newer TW titles. Naval battles in Medieval 2 are simple. You build a fleet and all battles are auto resolved. Easy, fast and out of the way so you can concentrate on the really fun stuff - land battles and expansion. I don't know if I'm alone in thinking that naval battles are trash and have ruined the newer TW games, but you definitely don't have to worry about that in this game.There are a lot of factions you can play and they all have small differences but you can generalize all of them into 4 super factions that share a lot of similar traits and units: western Europe, eastern Europe, north Africa and middle east. Playing through the campaign as different factions is fun and rewarding.The bottom line is this game is pretty amazing and you should definitely give it a try.

												The Total War game that had everything. The newer iterations of the series keep removing features and depth to the game.Obviously this is not a perfect game, the engine can only run in 1 CPU core and that really hurts when having a huge battle with unlimited units on the field.It has lots of exploits and bugs, the pikemen are basically useless. The vanilla AI has some serious issues with pathfinding, especially when you select a group of units and try to move them in a siege battle.Now, most of this issues, except of course those caused by the engine itself are addressed by the excellent modding community this game STILL has. Go browse the Total War Center website and see by yourself the mods this game has to offer. Recommended at full price.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												My favorite game of all time, and one of the best, if not THE best, Total War titles.It doesn't have the improved politics, economy, replenishemnt, and public order systems of the later titles, but it M2 has it where it counts, visceral battles, free-form campaigns, amazing soundtrack, and a lot of personality that the later titles have lost. Before I had the steam version I logged 600 hours on this game, and that was WITHOUT mods. The major strength is that you can pretty much play the campaigns any way you want with minimal interference from the "story" , unlike Napoleon, R2, and Attila. You create your own history instead of being pushed into following actual history.The AI might be a bit dumb and it has its fair sure of bugs and glitches, but there's no DLC.Supposedly the latest steam version doesn't let you use certain mods, hasn't been an issue for me. I'd recommend two mods that I always use: Retrofit (takes kindoms features into the M2 grand campaign) and Crimson Tide (lots more blood and dirt).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												I am finally writing a review about this game.  I did play this game for many hours(it reset after deleting the game due to mod problems) and don't believe adding another review will help an older and known game as such.  However, I do write this review in hopes to provide a small aid to communities that are trying to revert Total War series to what it was.  I love Rome II and liked Attila.  The graphcis, battles and the settings were all to my likings.  However, they seem to lack so much compared to Medieval II.  The campaign in Medieval II are so much more dramatic and rich with random events that all together weave a great story.  The Crusade and the Pope, Jihad, and Americas made the campaign much more interesting than just alliance wars.  I can sit here and list all the features that I like better than the newer games.  The newers games do have impressive visuals and smoother combat, as Medieval units sometimes seem completely mindless of the battle.  As far as the advantage of the newer games go, that is it.  Overall, Medieval II has much more culture varieties, random happenings to keep the faction instable, and more events to drive the campaign and make it feel fresh even after several turns.  When the next historical Total War comes out, I believe it should model itself more like Medieval II than the newer games.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												My friend Kept the bulk of his filthy lowborn Braveheart Wannabe forces in the town centre so I surrounded it and charged in with the glorious British Super Whale Knight Heavy Assualt Squad(If you get that reference you can have a cookie)! What a foolish tactic-- Hey what are those flaming arrows doing?"OH GOD THE CITY IS ON FIRE!, MY FRIEND IS ON FIRE!, AND SO IS MY FACE!, EVERYONE PANIC AND RUN!" -- My supposed elite force as archers rain destruction all over the angles of retreat and through the slits of my Knights' helmets10/10 Would be outsmarted by disposable Peasant bait again and set on fire for my Hubris, A truly SHAMEFURDISPR-- Oh wrong game :PWhat I am trying to say is:+ Tactics are the core of this game, a smart commander can win with nearly any competent force composition as opposed to just buying top tier unit spam.+ Great Political/Kingdom Management System outside of battles.+ Ungodly 22 factions, each with their own nuances and tactics to master, but still realistic.+Beautifully done melee and archery combat, the fights are fully animated with their own brutal kills and flying corpses, which is kind of a must for a medieval RTS- Learning Curve is not for the faint of heart- Games take a very long time, especially when good players can fight each other to a stand still- Sometimes its unclear how quickly your units break, especially in some circumstances where they seem like they will win, but the AI is generally very good and this along with a few smattering of bugs (Not on Rome TW2 Level) make up a small portion of the Game Overall.9/10 one of the best in the series next to Shogun and won't require any too fancy a PC to run me thinks hMMM? So what is your excuse hmm?, picking this up, you should be! -- Yoda

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												Medieval II: Total War has to be my current favorite of the Total War series. I'll get the bad parts out of the way first...Issuing commands to units can sometimes be clunky, such as cavalry not pursuing broken enemies or simply dancing around them without actually killing or capturing any, or only a minor percentage of soldiers actually complying with your order to march, run or charge. Moving troops through settlements can be irritating as well as they often decide against using a straight path leading to the centre because it's slightly more narrow than the normal pathways.The AI in the campaign also behaves with very little forward thinking, even on the hardest difficulty, being more than willing to break off an alliance and trade rights for the sake of attacking a settlement that is lightly defended, or to blockade an empty port for some extra money, oblivious to the outcome of their actions. Diplomacy can be irritating in later turns, especially against enemy factions, even when they are completely outmatched they will stubbornly refuse a ceasefire even at the cost of total defeat, all because of a war that started with a minor battle over some trivial port or minor town. The chivalry/ dread levels are only of real use for role play, if you're just going for world domination it's completely pointless. Finally the agents skills don't appear to be as relevant to successful missions as they should be, I myself have experienced a surprisingly high number of failed acquisitions, spy infiltrations, etc despite the chance of success being at 95%So what do I actually LIKE about this game? For one. the time period. Western Europe is struggling to recover from the fall of Western Rome, the surviving Eastern Empire struggles to reclaim it's losses while fending off the strength of the Turks, the Reconquista in Iberia, the Crusades to reclaim the lands that saw the birth of Christianity and so much more.Unit types still follow patterns of weaknesses/ strengths similar to the system in Rome TW but has been adapted to fit medieval warfare very well. Knights, while they are of a high quality, are not overpowered super-soldiers and in the early campaign their costly upkeep makes them a less appealing choice. I also really admire how weapon and armour upgrades are actually visible on the soldiers now. While weapon upgrades are limited to bronze and armours varying from Gold to non-existent, it adds more realism to the situation. The type of armour also varies depending on the type of unit - Light or Heavy.The campaign, while irritating at times, does have some feeling of authenticity to it. The AI behaves in a way that leaves you wondering "what are you thinking?" which matches the unpredictable nature of any human, often acting in a way that leaves outsiders confused at their motivations or goals. Diplomacy can be tricky as even establishing trade with a faction, for example France, can lead to a rival of that faction becoming hostile toward you. If you want to play this game diplomatically then I wish you luck because politics in this campaign are very delicate and complicated right from the get go. The campaign continues to flow forward with new developments always happening, new technologies from Asia to learn and master, new locations to go to and discover, new enemies to face or evade and the constant concerns of managing your country to adapt and survive an ever changing world.Then there's the inclusion of settlement types - cultural and military hubs. Instead of building armies inside your own cities you now focus the military in castles while cities are used for finance, religion and more cultural acitivities. Managing which territories will house a castle/ city puts a new twist into the campaign in terms of growing your own faction, espionage and war in general. I.e. Taking enemy castles weakens their military but frees up their economy, taking enemy cities weakens their economy but leaves their military more intact.To sum up, this game has my favorite campaign of the series thus far and battles, while not my favorite, can still be entertaining and still presents the same amount of challenge of previous installments. I would rate this game 8/10 very good, not perfect but I would recommend it for any fan of of the series and any fan of turn based strategy.

												I bought this game originally by the DVD, the gold edition. It was the first Total War game I'd ever played. It made me play Rome: Total War, and then I explored the rest of the series. I fell in love with this game at first sight. I found this game by a youtube series that was really interactive. It was amazing. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												"What is best in life?""To crush God's enemies,to see them converted before you,and to hear the lamentations of their Imams."-Conan the Barbarian (said during his stint as a mercenary for the Pope)Seriously though, this game is still awesome, even after all these years later! In fact, M2:TW just celebrated its 10th birthday, this November 2016! And its still easily one of the best, if not the best, of the Total War series!Improving upon, and outdoing most everything in the previous M:TW and Rome:TW (whose engine it uses) games, Medieval II was a triumph of RTS when it was first released. And a year later, it only got better with the best Total War expansion to date, Kingdoms. And thats not even considering all the many wonderful fan-made mods this title has available, thus extending its greatness even more so! Even fantasy lands are game! Want to wage war in Middle-Earth? There's a mod for that! Feel like fighting for The Elder Scrolls' Tamriel? There's a mod for that! How about waylaying the Warhammer world? Well, actually, that game was released earlier this year. But..there's still mods that predate that!Caution: this game is a time consumer! You can EASILY spend 50+ hours on just one campaign alone, and given that there are 17 playable factions available (eventually) in just the base game alone, and that there is NO END DATE for any campaign (only an end to the campaign objectives, but the game still goes on, so you can play a medieval kingdom all the way into the 21st century and beyond, take that modernity! #ProgressIsForSuckers), you can rack up a kingdom's worth of time spent on this game! Rome wasn't built in a day, they say, but it sure was completed faster than this game is!Whether it be conquering your back-stabbing neighbors (all the italian powers, always!!), managing your empire (where is the govenator when you need him?), retaking the Holy Land from the infidel (ya jerks!), converting the heathen (come on fellas, its "A.D." now, get with the program already!), or making a heroic last stand for all of Christendom against the rapacious onslaught of the Golden Horde (which is what you get when you don't tip the chinese food delivery guy on one too many occasions), yes sir, Medieval II has it all. Even the possibility of having one of your generals get so cuckholded by his nakedly adulterous wife, that he loses it, becomes the most shameless man on earth, and shacks up with a tranny, thus bringing eternal shame to your kingdom! As I said, Medieval II has it all. Even things the developers really should have just left alone...*ahem*.If your a strategy gaming fan, there are certain games in the genre you just have to have played in your lifetime, like Age of Empires II: Age of Kings. This is that kind of game. Don't miss out. And here's to hoping that the developers go back on their "we don't make games with the number '3' in their titles" statement, and, once they are done with (the also fantastic, well-worth-your-time) Warhammer: Total War, they start developing Medieval III. Deus Vult, Creative Assembly, Deus Vult!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 26
TL;DRI got to execute the Pope, declare a Crusade on the Holy Roman Empire, and conquer the world and spread Milanese Italian fashion under the flag of Duke Bernardo the Mad, son of Duke Giorgio the Cuckold.9/10A MUST HAVE MEDIEVAL GENOCIDE SIMULATORPersonal InsightsThere's a myriad of sources out there that can cover the intricacies of gameplay far better than I could, so I'll try not to waste your time reading my review, when you could be in Medieval II fighting off 8 invading factions simultaneously, and outsmarting every enemy general on the battlefield.The GoodOutmaneuver enemy armies of better equipped knights and professional crossbowmen and win by epic, narrow margins with your  town militia and peasant archers in the early game, then laugh when you yourself raise armies of knights, and crush peasant armies with K/D ratios of 1:100 in the late game when you have so much excessive gold, you find yourself building Huge Cathedrals and Brothels in every corner of your empire just to drain your bloated treasury.There is no better feeling than when you've crushed all other factions except Denmark, Russia, Turkey, and Egypt, who then decide to form a super-alliance to prevent you from conquering the 20 remaining territories on the map, which you then do anyway.Unrest growing in a city? Raise taxes to Very High, move your entire garrison outside the city, and then wait. When the city rebels in 3-5 turns, besiege the city, kill the rebel soldiers, and then exterminate the populace to reestablish peace in your empire.Tired of using battering rams? Send 5 spies into an enemy castle for guaranteed access to Didney Worl! Laugh as the gates open as your troops surge through, and kill the French King to punish them for their crime of daring to proclaim French cuisine as superior to Italian.Artillery Elephants.When your general kills enough prisoners of war and exterminates the populations of enough cities, he can earn the epithet, "The Butcher". With 10 stars of command and 10 skulls of dread, Bindello the Butcher held off the Mongol invaders with little more than armies of Spear Militia and Peasant Crossbowmen. Unfortunately for him, Bindello the Butcher eventually died in an earthquake when I sent him to retire on the Iberian Peninsula.The BadVanilla AI sometimes fails to attack you with large enough armies. Vanilla AI sometimes lets you siege their capital for several turns, even though they have a full army nearby that could attack your besieging army, and break the siege.Executing Prisoners makes your faction "Untrustworthy". Why should enforcing capital punishment have any effect on trust?Vanilla AI will break a 50+ year old alliance to attack one of your lowest income villages, even though your army, wealth, and territories outnumber theirs by a ratio of 6:1.Vanilla AI will declare war by blockading one of your ports, and then failing to attack or do anything else for the next 80 years.Although Battle AI is mostly competent, if not brilliant, there have been a few scenarios in which opposing generals appear brain dead. If you siege a castle, and the AI has external reinforcements, the reinforcements have a decent chance of just camping outside the castle, and letting you slaughter its defenders without trying to aid their own faction.OnlineOnline experiences are limited to battles in the base game, although it appears you can run hotseat campaigns in the expansions. My experience with online multiplayer as been extremely limited, as my first online match was this year, more than a decade after this game was released. Nevertheless, I have been extremely satisfied with the handful of matches that I have had. Be warned though; in 2017 and beyond, it will be hard, if not impossible, to join an open match. Join some Medieval II groups, or tell your friends to buy this game if you want the most out of the online battles.ModsMy recommendations for modding the game? Play the game totally Vanilla for at least one long Grand Campaign, and then think carefully about what you would like changed. I put in over 200 hours in the Vanilla game before deciding to provide some tweaks to add some more options for gameplay. My current mods include Ultimate AI for the Campaign AI, and about 8 changes to the game files. Those changes are:Movement Speed increase for agents (but not armies)Increasing Age limit for Generals, so my 10 Star Generals stop dying at age 60.Increased Garrisons (free upkeep slots) for Cities and CastlesTrainable GeneralsStronger Walls/Gates, to make sieges a bigger challenge.Added Schiltrom (defense formation) to more unitsMisc. Diplomacy Fixes (easier Military Access)Misc. Mission FixesClosing ThoughtsMy experience with the Total War series actually began with the original Medieval: Total War. Medieval II has proven to be an improvement over nearly every asset of that game, and is actually compatible with modern hardware. If you like any other of the games in the Total War series, fictional Medieval scenarios, RTS's, or Eurocentricism simulators, I strongly recommend this game.TL;DRAs Milan, my faction was excommunicated for failing to stop annexing the territories of my Catholic neighbors. The Pope declared a Crusade to take back Rome, which I had annexed from the Papal States several turns earlier. Seeing as I controlled all of Europe except for England at that point, I decided to hunker down at Rome, and let the lone English Crusading army actually reach its intended destination. At Rome, I had a full garrison of high quality Milanese militia, led by three generals. Outside of Rome, I had placed another full army ouside the gates as reinforcements. When the English Crusaders arrived, I was somewhat worried, as the English had brought proper Knights and Armored Swordsmen, whereas I had Spear Militia and Cavalry Militia. Nevertheless, I waited for the English assault. Sure enough, the English began their assault on the walls of Rome with catapults and trebuchets. Yet, they never managed to see Rome's interior. My Cavalry Militia sallied out of the gates, and killed the artillery crew, while my reinforcements attacked the would-be Crusaders from the rear. The English Crusading army was destroyed, and as equal and just retaliation, I annexed the entire British Isles and exterminated their citizens for good measure.9/10This game is Machiavelli's wet dream.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												Medieval II: Total War has to be my current favorite of the Total War series. I'll get the bad parts out of the way first...Issuing commands to units can sometimes be clunky, such as cavalry not pursuing broken enemies or simply dancing around them without actually killing or capturing any, or only a minor percentage of soldiers actually complying with your order to march, run or charge. Moving troops through settlements can be irritating as well as they often decide against using a straight path leading to the centre because it's slightly more narrow than the normal pathways.The AI in the campaign also behaves with very little forward thinking, even on the hardest difficulty, being more than willing to break off an alliance and trade rights for the sake of attacking a settlement that is lightly defended, or to blockade an empty port for some extra money, oblivious to the outcome of their actions. Diplomacy can be irritating in later turns, especially against enemy factions, even when they are completely outmatched they will stubbornly refuse a ceasefire even at the cost of total defeat, all because of a war that started with a minor battle over some trivial port or minor town. The chivalry/ dread levels are only of real use for role play, if you're just going for world domination it's completely pointless. Finally the agents skills don't appear to be as relevant to successful missions as they should be, I myself have experienced a surprisingly high number of failed acquisitions, spy infiltrations, etc despite the chance of success being at 95%So what do I actually LIKE about this game? For one. the time period. Western Europe is struggling to recover from the fall of Western Rome, the surviving Eastern Empire struggles to reclaim it's losses while fending off the strength of the Turks, the Reconquista in Iberia, the Crusades to reclaim the lands that saw the birth of Christianity and so much more.Unit types still follow patterns of weaknesses/ strengths similar to the system in Rome TW but has been adapted to fit medieval warfare very well. Knights, while they are of a high quality, are not overpowered super-soldiers and in the early campaign their costly upkeep makes them a less appealing choice. I also really admire how weapon and armour upgrades are actually visible on the soldiers now. While weapon upgrades are limited to bronze and armours varying from Gold to non-existent, it adds more realism to the situation. The type of armour also varies depending on the type of unit - Light or Heavy.The campaign, while irritating at times, does have some feeling of authenticity to it. The AI behaves in a way that leaves you wondering "what are you thinking?" which matches the unpredictable nature of any human, often acting in a way that leaves outsiders confused at their motivations or goals. Diplomacy can be tricky as even establishing trade with a faction, for example France, can lead to a rival of that faction becoming hostile toward you. If you want to play this game diplomatically then I wish you luck because politics in this campaign are very delicate and complicated right from the get go. The campaign continues to flow forward with new developments always happening, new technologies from Asia to learn and master, new locations to go to and discover, new enemies to face or evade and the constant concerns of managing your country to adapt and survive an ever changing world.Then there's the inclusion of settlement types - cultural and military hubs. Instead of building armies inside your own cities you now focus the military in castles while cities are used for finance, religion and more cultural acitivities. Managing which territories will house a castle/ city puts a new twist into the campaign in terms of growing your own faction, espionage and war in general. I.e. Taking enemy castles weakens their military but frees up their economy, taking enemy cities weakens their economy but leaves their military more intact.To sum up, this game has my favorite campaign of the series thus far and battles, while not my favorite, can still be entertaining and still presents the same amount of challenge of previous installments. I would rate this game 8/10 very good, not perfect but I would recommend it for any fan of of the series and any fan of turn based strategy.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												Quite a good base game. 9.2/10Pros-Very balanced. Good for multiplayer battles.-Great, intense battles!-Large map-Graphics are pretty good for the time.-Can be challenging if you want it to be.-Doing crusades can be fun.-Merchants can help you financially.-Burning heretics.-Discovery of America gives a new objective to the base campaign (extermination of the Native Americans)-Factions generally  follow historical accuracy.-As goes with most Total War games you can do whatever you want.-The ability to take over the Catholic church.-Variation of tower defenses and boats.-Siege battles are fun.-Relations between factions.-Cool cutscenes -When talking through diplomacy the characters you speak to use the accents that would be typical to their country. Cons-Autocompletion isn't great unless you are on Easy difficulty.-Most factions stay loyal to the Catholic church despite the hatred of the Catholic church in this time period. Meaning there is no Protestant formation. (This is more of a nitpick though)-Can't play as the Mongols or Timurids without messing with the game files :(-Inquisitors. Way too many Inquisitors.-If you want to do something fun the Pope hates whatever it is.-Diplomacy can be odd sometimes-Crusade targets are hard to get to. The soldiers also will desert if you don't get to the target fast enough.-Rival merchants stealing resources.-When invading the Americas you are limited to the Yucatán Peninsula, South eastern north america, and Brazil. (In the DLC you can do much more in a specific Americas campaign) -The Pope often gets mad. Generally after he asks you to do a very hard and stupid task.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												I have been playing this game well before it was put on Steam. I'm actually really happy its on Steam now since I lost my old CD keys, this game is quite a gem. This Total War game is the one I compare every Total War game to and none of them ever come close to this one in terms of fun and replayability. The seige battles for both attack and defence in this game feel genuinely better than the ones in future installments. They are satisfying to play, whether you are taking down the walls with catapults/cannons, storming a citadel with seige equipment like rams and ladders, or just defending against invading forces storming your city.The units in this game matter, but its how you use them that makes for the most interesting battles. Clearly when the professional (late game) units go up against peasants and such, especially in an open field, we know who is ultimately going to lose (in most cases), but with right combination of units, including peasants, and the right kind of placement, you can easily defending a settlement against even the most advanced/elite units. This also depends on difficulty too as the AI can be vicious if given the chance.I aslo enjoyed the religion system in this game, but mainly for the catholic factions. The Papal states are not a minor faction and they will wreck you with not only their own units (which are pretty powerful) but all of Christendom will come together to crusade your face in should you get excommunicated or if the pope doesn't favor your faction nearly as much as the others (meaning he'll look the other way for a bit). For what it is, it is a complex, but straightforward system that can either be used to your advantage or used against you. The modding community for this game is pretty awesome too. Hyrule: Total War and Stainless Steel are both mods I love and they work so well with this game that it gives me endless hours of entertainment even to this day. The game still has a rather active modding community for something of its age, which is great since it just makes a great game even better. Finally, the game is just all around fun. How you play this game can easily make for a great time or just a great way to waste time in general all the while being entertained. I wish Sega and the Total War series in general looked back to this game and Rome: Total War (the first one) to see what they got so right about their game series and just put that + whatever improvements and mechanics (like naval battles) into the game. If they were to make a modern day version of this game with everything that made this game great, I would buy it in a heartbeat. But in the meantime, there is this game, so if you are looking to pick it up, do so and enjoy!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 26
TL;DRI got to execute the Pope, declare a Crusade on the Holy Roman Empire, and conquer the world and spread Milanese Italian fashion under the flag of Duke Bernardo the Mad, son of Duke Giorgio the Cuckold.9/10A MUST HAVE MEDIEVAL GENOCIDE SIMULATORPersonal InsightsThere's a myriad of sources out there that can cover the intricacies of gameplay far better than I could, so I'll try not to waste your time reading my review, when you could be in Medieval II fighting off 8 invading factions simultaneously, and outsmarting every enemy general on the battlefield.The GoodOutmaneuver enemy armies of better equipped knights and professional crossbowmen and win by epic, narrow margins with your  town militia and peasant archers in the early game, then laugh when you yourself raise armies of knights, and crush peasant armies with K/D ratios of 1:100 in the late game when you have so much excessive gold, you find yourself building Huge Cathedrals and Brothels in every corner of your empire just to drain your bloated treasury.There is no better feeling than when you've crushed all other factions except Denmark, Russia, Turkey, and Egypt, who then decide to form a super-alliance to prevent you from conquering the 20 remaining territories on the map, which you then do anyway.Unrest growing in a city? Raise taxes to Very High, move your entire garrison outside the city, and then wait. When the city rebels in 3-5 turns, besiege the city, kill the rebel soldiers, and then exterminate the populace to reestablish peace in your empire.Tired of using battering rams? Send 5 spies into an enemy castle for guaranteed access to Didney Worl! Laugh as the gates open as your troops surge through, and kill the French King to punish them for their crime of daring to proclaim French cuisine as superior to Italian.Artillery Elephants.When your general kills enough prisoners of war and exterminates the populations of enough cities, he can earn the epithet, "The Butcher". With 10 stars of command and 10 skulls of dread, Bindello the Butcher held off the Mongol invaders with little more than armies of Spear Militia and Peasant Crossbowmen. Unfortunately for him, Bindello the Butcher eventually died in an earthquake when I sent him to retire on the Iberian Peninsula.The BadVanilla AI sometimes fails to attack you with large enough armies. Vanilla AI sometimes lets you siege their capital for several turns, even though they have a full army nearby that could attack your besieging army, and break the siege.Executing Prisoners makes your faction "Untrustworthy". Why should enforcing capital punishment have any effect on trust?Vanilla AI will break a 50+ year old alliance to attack one of your lowest income villages, even though your army, wealth, and territories outnumber theirs by a ratio of 6:1.Vanilla AI will declare war by blockading one of your ports, and then failing to attack or do anything else for the next 80 years.Although Battle AI is mostly competent, if not brilliant, there have been a few scenarios in which opposing generals appear brain dead. If you siege a castle, and the AI has external reinforcements, the reinforcements have a decent chance of just camping outside the castle, and letting you slaughter its defenders without trying to aid their own faction.OnlineOnline experiences are limited to battles in the base game, although it appears you can run hotseat campaigns in the expansions. My experience with online multiplayer as been extremely limited, as my first online match was this year, more than a decade after this game was released. Nevertheless, I have been extremely satisfied with the handful of matches that I have had. Be warned though; in 2017 and beyond, it will be hard, if not impossible, to join an open match. Join some Medieval II groups, or tell your friends to buy this game if you want the most out of the online battles.ModsMy recommendations for modding the game? Play the game totally Vanilla for at least one long Grand Campaign, and then think carefully about what you would like changed. I put in over 200 hours in the Vanilla game before deciding to provide some tweaks to add some more options for gameplay. My current mods include Ultimate AI for the Campaign AI, and about 8 changes to the game files. Those changes are:Movement Speed increase for agents (but not armies)Increasing Age limit for Generals, so my 10 Star Generals stop dying at age 60.Increased Garrisons (free upkeep slots) for Cities and CastlesTrainable GeneralsStronger Walls/Gates, to make sieges a bigger challenge.Added Schiltrom (defense formation) to more unitsMisc. Diplomacy Fixes (easier Military Access)Misc. Mission FixesClosing ThoughtsMy experience with the Total War series actually began with the original Medieval: Total War. Medieval II has proven to be an improvement over nearly every asset of that game, and is actually compatible with modern hardware. If you like any other of the games in the Total War series, fictional Medieval scenarios, RTS's, or Eurocentricism simulators, I strongly recommend this game.TL;DRAs Milan, my faction was excommunicated for failing to stop annexing the territories of my Catholic neighbors. The Pope declared a Crusade to take back Rome, which I had annexed from the Papal States several turns earlier. Seeing as I controlled all of Europe except for England at that point, I decided to hunker down at Rome, and let the lone English Crusading army actually reach its intended destination. At Rome, I had a full garrison of high quality Milanese militia, led by three generals. Outside of Rome, I had placed another full army ouside the gates as reinforcements. When the English Crusaders arrived, I was somewhat worried, as the English had brought proper Knights and Armored Swordsmen, whereas I had Spear Militia and Cavalry Militia. Nevertheless, I waited for the English assault. Sure enough, the English began their assault on the walls of Rome with catapults and trebuchets. Yet, they never managed to see Rome's interior. My Cavalry Militia sallied out of the gates, and killed the artillery crew, while my reinforcements attacked the would-be Crusaders from the rear. The English Crusading army was destroyed, and as equal and just retaliation, I annexed the entire British Isles and exterminated their citizens for good measure.9/10This game is Machiavelli's wet dream.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												"What is best in life?""To crush God's enemies,to see them converted before you,and to hear the lamentations of their Imams."-Conan the Barbarian (said during his stint as a mercenary for the Pope)Seriously though, this game is still awesome, even after all these years later! In fact, M2:TW just celebrated its 10th birthday, this November 2016! And its still easily one of the best, if not the best, of the Total War series!Improving upon, and outdoing most everything in the previous M:TW and Rome:TW (whose engine it uses) games, Medieval II was a triumph of RTS when it was first released. And a year later, it only got better with the best Total War expansion to date, Kingdoms. And thats not even considering all the many wonderful fan-made mods this title has available, thus extending its greatness even more so! Even fantasy lands are game! Want to wage war in Middle-Earth? There's a mod for that! Feel like fighting for The Elder Scrolls' Tamriel? There's a mod for that! How about waylaying the Warhammer world? Well, actually, that game was released earlier this year. But..there's still mods that predate that!Caution: this game is a time consumer! You can EASILY spend 50+ hours on just one campaign alone, and given that there are 17 playable factions available (eventually) in just the base game alone, and that there is NO END DATE for any campaign (only an end to the campaign objectives, but the game still goes on, so you can play a medieval kingdom all the way into the 21st century and beyond, take that modernity! #ProgressIsForSuckers), you can rack up a kingdom's worth of time spent on this game! Rome wasn't built in a day, they say, but it sure was completed faster than this game is!Whether it be conquering your back-stabbing neighbors (all the italian powers, always!!), managing your empire (where is the govenator when you need him?), retaking the Holy Land from the infidel (ya jerks!), converting the heathen (come on fellas, its "A.D." now, get with the program already!), or making a heroic last stand for all of Christendom against the rapacious onslaught of the Golden Horde (which is what you get when you don't tip the chinese food delivery guy on one too many occasions), yes sir, Medieval II has it all. Even the possibility of having one of your generals get so cuckholded by his nakedly adulterous wife, that he loses it, becomes the most shameless man on earth, and shacks up with a tranny, thus bringing eternal shame to your kingdom! As I said, Medieval II has it all. Even things the developers really should have just left alone...*ahem*.If your a strategy gaming fan, there are certain games in the genre you just have to have played in your lifetime, like Age of Empires II: Age of Kings. This is that kind of game. Don't miss out. And here's to hoping that the developers go back on their "we don't make games with the number '3' in their titles" statement, and, once they are done with (the also fantastic, well-worth-your-time) Warhammer: Total War, they start developing Medieval III. Deus Vult, Creative Assembly, Deus Vult!

content:
Posted: March 2
												This is an excellent entry in the Total War series, better than its predecessor (Rome) and its next 2 successors (Empire and Napolean). The time period allows for exciting gameplay and lots of variety. The campaign mode fixed a lot of the problems from Rome (late game issues like being unable to deal with large cities and distance from capital). This game also introduced randomization of soldiers, so they all look different instead of being an army of clones. This game has one of the best experiences of building a globe spanning kingdom from 1 or 2 settlements. AI isn't amazing, but smart enough to put you in some tough situations now and again, especially on higher difficulty settings.DLC campaigns are fun and add interesting scenarios.All in all, lots of fun, tons of nations to play with, meaningful differences in unit types, and challenging strategy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2016
												This game is one of the best Total War games, in my opinion at least, to this day. My review is pretty late. Don't let my hours fool you, since I played lots of the disc copy before I got it on steam. The campaign is great, and features a lot of historically accurate versions of countries/kingdoms/empires for it's time. I'd reccommend it to anyone, new and old, to the Total War franchise. It's also worth picking up the Kingdoms expansion, as it features 4 campaingns, new units and features, and it can make a few mods a lot more viable without having to replace the base game. But yeah, this game's modding community is reasonably active, with lots of great mods such as Stainless Steel and Third Age Total War, this game really is worth it. It's also worth noting that the game is 10GB, later games being higher than that, so unless you are prepared to waste a lot of time on a poor connection, it's probably better to pick up a hard disc.

												Great game and the best of all the Total War series for me personally, partly because of the time period and partly because of it being the first Total War game I ever bought. It has some issues now in terms of poor wide screen support and stuff like difficulty of mod installing for steam version, but its still a great and addictive game. Over the years communnity around it made it only better with lots of amazing mods like LotR themed Third Age:Total War and Warhammer fantasy themed Age Of Warhammer:Total War(which is btw without doubt is one of the reasons we get Warhammer:Total War now). I played hundreds of hours of this game and never got tired of it, and I could tell you hell of a lot of stories what happened within it in that time, but it would take too long. So just know that like any good game, this one allows you to come up with stories of your own while having a great time playing and enjoying most of its aspects.

												my favorite total war game in the series.  you'll spend hours fighting, conquering and most importantly having fun. the game is  full of tiny details that seem to never make it in contemporary titles. the sound effects and music give a truly medieval feeling and the battles are simply epic, from grand decisive battles with full stacks, to minor skirmishes with small groups of soldiers. this game is the peak of the total war games and combines the best features that were removed along with excellence that inspires players to continue to play the newer titles. if you were a fan of the newer or older games in the total war series, or if you are looking for a fun new game you haven't played before, I highly suggest you pick this up.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2016
												Old game, but in my opinion, still the best Total War game out there. This puppy here became my first dream come true concerning world domination! 10 years on, I finally have a grasp on the game and all it's aspects and still learn something new everytime I install it and take it for a spin.Vanilla has plenty to offer for various playthroughs, once that's doesn't do it anymore, you're free to change many things in the game files to increase the difficulty of the game or get rid of some annoyances. If you want to get away from Vanilla however, then there's more to offer in the form of mods. Many mods either completely overhaul the game and there are others that bring changes to the existing game and expand on the European theathre. The only other game I've found that had such an extinsive amount of overhaul mods it's Mount and Blade Warband, which, by all rights, is another great game. Where Warband puts you in the thick of the action, Medieval 2 allows you to direct all the action.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												My favorite game of all time, and one of the best, if not THE best, Total War titles.It doesn't have the improved politics, economy, replenishemnt, and public order systems of the later titles, but it M2 has it where it counts, visceral battles, free-form campaigns, amazing soundtrack, and a lot of personality that the later titles have lost. Before I had the steam version I logged 600 hours on this game, and that was WITHOUT mods. The major strength is that you can pretty much play the campaigns any way you want with minimal interference from the "story" , unlike Napoleon, R2, and Attila. You create your own history instead of being pushed into following actual history.The AI might be a bit dumb and it has its fair sure of bugs and glitches, but there's no DLC.Supposedly the latest steam version doesn't let you use certain mods, hasn't been an issue for me. I'd recommend two mods that I always use: Retrofit (takes kindoms features into the M2 grand campaign) and Crimson Tide (lots more blood and dirt).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												I have Medieval 2 and Kingdoms on disc already and I only recently bought this on Steam again as a backup. I have sunk countless hours on the disc version.This game is a massive improvement on Rome 1 that was before this and of course is far better with the amount of mods that are availiable for it. Especially if you have the Kingdoms Expansion which I recomend you should get as well. Vanilla is very good and holds its own but like most Total Wargames it is improved further with mods. To improve historical accuracy and provide total overhauls. I recomend you have a look on twcenter.net for what modders have made availiable. This game covers 300 years of history from just after the Norman invasion of Britain, the Crusades, the Mongol invasion, the discovery of gun powder to the exploring of the Americas. I don't think i'll ever get bored with this game as I've always come back to it even after playing more recent games such as Shogun 2, Empire and Rome 2 which I also enjoy. So my love for this game has not anything to do with rose tinted glasses.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												In my opinion, this is still the king of medieval strategy games. While Crusader Kings II can't really be topped in terms of depth and the sheer amount of intricacy on offer, at the time of its release Medieval II offered players a chance at some cunning diplomacy using spies, priests and even princesses to influence the enemy factions, in addition to an updated battle engine.Definitely worth picking up, especially if you're curious about the more recent Total War games and want a slightly less complex entry into the military strategy world.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												It says that I have 463 hours on this game but since I played it back when the Kingdoms launcher was mixed with the regular one, it should be near a thousand. This is THE game to play if you are into medieval style strategy games with a heavy emphasis on combat. You can play as the already might Holy Roman Empire or start off as Scotland and create a new empire through conquest. The game play itself is done in a way where even if you have never played a strategy game before, you will soon be able to understand and pick up the time of game play this game has to offer. What makes this game even more amazing is the modding community behind it. This is easily one of my all time favorite games and I recommend that anyone who can get their hands on it should play it.10/10

												Medieval II: Total War, where to even begin? Before I even bought this game on Steam I had over 1000 hours on it and thats without even having mods! The DLC Kingdoms is probably one of the best expansions for a Total War game ever, from adding four new campaigns to all the mods you can have! My favorite mod would have to the Third Age Total War which is basically a COMPLETE conversion of the base game into the world of J. R. R. Tolkien and you can fight the war of Middle Earth from a startegy perspective! I never really play the multiplayer to be honest because I'm mainly a singleplayer kinda guy when it comes to Total War games. I would highly recommend you to buy this game along with the DLC Kingdoms so you have (again) the four new Campaigns and all the mods! 10/10

												Last of the pre-Warscape engine Total War games, M2TW is still one of the best in the series. Once you finish them, it's time to donwload some of the many mods that are constanly being churned out even so many years after this game was released.

FIRST OF ALLFirst of all i'd like to say that i'm not going to review this game basing on what people say or else and that i am a fan of the Total War saga,i own every total war title,except from attila,3 of them on steam and the other ones on DVD so i'm going to be really precise and straight in this review.The good points.This game has some key points that makes it one of the best,if not the best,Total War title.-Game has just made steps forward and none backwards from its predecessor,Rome.-Campaign AI is Smart and operates well-Jihads and Crusuades are super fun.-Now you have a reason to defeat a enemy family member,because his ransom will gain you an absurd ammount of money.-Many units to choose from-Best overall Total War title in my Opinion.The bad points-Too much inaggressive AI,it will rarely attack you.-Sometimes your allies betray you for no reason at all.-Pope excomunicates you even if you dont smile at him when he walks near you-AI Sometimes lays some suicidal sieges with the leader of his faction toward a full fortified town.-Pathfinding is terrible. number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												When I chose Very Hard Campaign mode, I didn't just expect all of the other nations to despise me and their diplomats to be completely unyielding in their offers. "Become a vassal" was the only option I ever had when trying to negotiate a peace deal with Hungary, even though we, The Holy Roman Empire, had been fighting a war in which tens of thousands had died during a period of over 100 turns without any significant changes in the war. Despite this, Hungary, which at this point was the most powerful nation in the world,( the HRE being second despite endless attacks by also Milan, Venice, France,Denmark and the Moors, which also all lasted 50 -100+ turns without any peace seen except with the Moors) continued to attack ME, even though it was clear that I could always barely irk by despite my desire for peace and my many attempts to SEE peace through acts of goodwill by releasing their endlesss armies of men only for them to attack me once anew. That being said, when I chose Very Hard Combat mode, I expected a challenge, not in that the enemy forces would just have superior forces and troops, but that the enemy generals, atleast when it happened to be a unique character with good command, would be at all competent in their decision making, and not that they would just let my cavalry always destroy their artillery and missile infantry as they were never in a position to defend them.Having played CK2 for 100s of hours, I can say that the diplomacy system and the general decision-making of other nations is not only extensively dumbed down(which is not that big of a deal since Total War is mostly centralized around battles) but also completely unreasonable. I did not ask for every major nation around me to declare war on me, I asked for a diplomacy system that would present an intriguing challenge, like in CK2. I still give it a 9/10, minus the serious AI and diplomacy issues it is still one of the most entertaining games I've ever played.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												I love this game, Medieval 2 Total War in my opinion is the best Total War game to date, Rome Total War polished, and I enjoy the medieval era more than the Roman era. Objectively speaking there is an undeniable quantity of value in this game, before I downloaded mods I had about 200 hours. The vanilla version of this game is excellent. I could even play the campaign mode of the vanilla version after playing the campaign mode of these mods. Battles in this game are the best it will ever be and with multiple medieval eras from early to high to late where you have musket men and cannons. I could have an army of Mongolian cavalry fight an army of French pikemen and musket men. Possibilities in the battles are endless! Also, battles require tactical positioning, flanking, planning and using your brain in general. If you don’t like to use your brain, than don’t buy this game. If you do, however, you will find very interesting and creative ways to defeat your enemies. When to attack the enemy or hold position and send spearmen to the front, when you should retreat or hold fast. There is just so much fun to have in battles. The Campaign mode has no story, like every other Total War game, based on the situation of your nation and other nations, plans and ambitions, you make your own story. Be the king of England and defeat the French once and for all, forge an empire of 2 land masses. Play as Byzantium and retake lost lands and lost lands of the Roman empire. When it comes to recruitment and construction it is balanced. Recruitment pools determine how many units you can recruit per turn and how long you must wait until you can recruit another one of the same unit. This prevents large and massive armies of heavy infantry running all over the place. Diplomacy feels real as in the medieval times there were no phones to call other leaders. Countries had to send a diplomat and wait for a response. Diplomacy is not as in depth as it could be, but this game is focused around war and military. Keep that in mind when you play the campaign mode. Trade, alliances, embargos, vassals, military access, the basics are all there. Events happen in the campaign mode throughout such as the Mongolian invasion, the discovery of gunpowder and the new world, and yes, this game includes the plague.Overall, unless you are too stupid to use your brain in coordination and deep thought, you will enjoy this game and get your money’s worth without a doubt. Even at full retail price I would still find my money’s worth. Go buy it on sale if you are still sceptical, I did it, too.I give this game a full 10/10!

content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												A fantastic game even by todays standards. The graphics are perfectly acceptable and game runs flawlessly. It has a lot of great additions and cool features like Princess', Priests etc. The campaign is very gripping and more challenging than most of the TW titles partly because of the size of the other factions. I really like the upgrading and recruiting system of Medieval 2 as unlike other TW games, you cant have the best soldiers in every settlement and often dont have a perfect army, so it forces you to thing and plan around your weaknesses. The soundtrack is also very good, it loads super fast and is a blast to play. I much prefer this game to Rome 2 and im convinced Medieval 2 is a close rival with Rome 1 to be the best TW game ever!!!!!Got to be rated a 5/5 or 9/10 - I defenitely recommend this game for peoples who like TW, or the Medieval period. But even if you have no interest in eather theres a good chance you will still love this game!!!!!!

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												I bought this game long ago on CD and recently rediscovered it on Steam. Thanks to Steam I was able to activate the game without purchase using my old CD key and got the Kingdoms expansion as bonus... great. Additionally being able to play this game on Linux is great...So this game feels deep and engrossing. There are so many options that it seems overwhelming at first. Luckily you are not drowning in micromanagement unlike some other games. And yes, battles are fun but you can choose to auto-resolve them if you are focussed on the bigger picture.So, the politics of this game seems very deep. I started out with Holy Roman Empire. I built a high standing with the Pope. Then allied with the Papal States. Pope called for a crusade. I didn't join initially. In the meantime the Pope died and elections were called for. My cardinal became the Pope. Immediately became the most favoured nation with Pope. Joined the crusade with my king at the head of the crusading army... What with managing your family tree, choosing your potential heirs, marrying off your family members, managing diplomacy with other factions etc. etc. you have your hands full. Unlike the Civ titles, there is no sense of randomness or emptiness when it comes to international politics as the game is founded in a historic setting, and every diplomatic move feels like it matters. Haven't played further, but looking forward to smashing the enemies!

content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
												After so long of not palying this game, I went back and played as both the Holy Roman Empire and England. I had completely forgotten just how much content depth this game has as well as the amazing dynamic combat and cavalry charges. Nothing beats watching your heavy mounted knights charge to the rear of enemy troops being held in place by your men-at-arms. There's always something to do in the game. Whether it's building up your empire with the constant upgrads to cities and castles, to you participating in crusades or squashing rebellions. And those general speaches are absolutely amazing. This game isn't without its faults. The ai can be quite stupid at times, but that's the case with all TW games so it isn't too bad considering it's not broken. The game itself (the campaign) has no real story but the one you make with whatever events unfold during your playtime. The game has 2 phases: one is a turn based campaign map where you manage your empire. How you manage your empire is really up to you but keep in mind that this isn't Rome 2 or Attila, there are consequences to your actions. Too much war mongering against other factions that share your religion and you'll be excommunicated by your religious leader meaning that you could find yourself in the middle of both a Jihad AND a holy crusade. Your generals are also EXTREMELY important! I cannot stress that enough! You need generals not only to lead your troops in battle, but also to build up your empire. If a city or castle doesn't have a governer (a general either a family member or just some general in your family) you cannot choose what to build or what units to recruit. It will be automanaged. One of the downsides to this game though is the annoyance of having to hire a diplomat in order to take diplomatic actions with other factions. It may be a bit more immersive, sure, but it's still a pain. that's one of the things newer TW games have done right. The game also has missions that are sent to you. From taking certain cities or castles to joining crusades, as stated before there's always something to do. However, some missions can be absolutely stupid and won't benifit you in any way or are nearly impossible to truly accomplish and it sucks because if they're not done, you lose reputation. be it with other factions or with your respective religious leader. But other than that, this game really doesn't have much to complain about. The 2nd phase is the real time battle map with thousands of men under your command. The best trategy here is the best strategy in any TW game: Take the high grounds and if none are available, use the "hammer and anvil strategy. It works extremely well in this game because of the powerful heavy cavalry. Overall this is a phenominal game and has earned all its praise and love. It's not perfect and has some glaring flaws, but they're easily overshadowed by the sheer amount of content and high quality of the game.
