content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												This is still the best Total War, and will continue to be the best Total War until Creative Assembly dumps the Warscape engine, which has become a serious handicap for every Total War after this one. That, and hiring competent AI programmers so they can stop oversimplifying and removing basic game mechanics just so that AI has less things to ♥♥♥♥ up.Here's a short list of things M2TW does better than the later titles:-To start, this is by far the most moddable Total War in the series. Everything from units to animations to the campaign and battle maps are completely moddable. Even the AI is moddable to a limited extent.-Has by far the best recruitment system of any Total War game. Every unit has a limited pool to recruit from that replenishes at variable rates based on the building they're recruited from. Higher quality professional soldiers replenished slower than lower quality militia units, which prevents churning out stacks of elite units in quick order, atleast until you get to the point where you own half of Europe. I'm actually baffled as to why they moved away from this, but it was probably due to Creative Assembly being incapable of making the AI work with it.-NO LIMITED BUILDING SLOT NONSENSE. And no idiotic food mechanics that further restricted your building choices either. In M2TW's cities/castles, you could pretty much build everything in every city/castle. BUT you can only build one building at a time, so to be optimal you still had to specialize each city/castle for a specific purpose early on. -Agents that actually served a strategic purpose, rather than just being a general nuisance or generic regional stat buff.-Battles that last more than 5 minutes. This is again probably due to CA's AI short comings, as the battle AI throughout the years has yet to evolve beyond "engage front line, flank with any extra cavaly, suicide general". The shorter the battles the are the less this is a problem, but the longer battles go it becomes easier for the player to out manuver and smash the AI.-Soldiers have actual mass. Heavier units will actually force weaker units backwards in melee. In the later Warscape plagued titles, a few dozen of the weakest unit imaginable can literally prevent hundreds of heavy infantry from moving forwards. -Sieges that were, at the very least, fun to defend and attack on. M2TW certainly has the most complicated siege battles, with the highest level castles having 3 sets of walls to overcome. The AI can have a tough time with it, but it usually does okay. Total War AI has always been a little extra special when it comes to siege battles, but other than Shogun 2 the AI has gotten significantly worse at them since M2TW, despite siege battles being significantly simplified.As superior M2TW undoubtably is, there are a number of things later Total Wars do better:-Graphics, an obvious one, though the graphics in M2TW still look pretty decent today.-UI. M2TW's UI is big, ugly, and clunky, and scales poorly on widescreen resolutions. Definitely has not aged well.-No ♥♥♥♥in diplomats. All diplomacy can be done instantly without the need of an agent running around all of Europe just to die of the plague right when you need him the most.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												I love this beauty of a game. I have spent a lot of time conquering the French, The Holy Roman Empire and Spain as England. Although I have yet to have an army of Dismounted English Knights, or Armoured Swordsmen legitimatly, I have only got up to a few of each in an army. There are countless mods for this game, making it even better. My favorites are Rage of Dark Gods, which takes place in the Warhammer universe. Another is Third Age, a Lord of the Rings mod. They are both great mods. I have spent countless hours on this game. Even though it says '99 Hours Played.' Thats a lie. I have played 200 hours easily in this game. Even when you have no internet, this game CAN be played. One of my go to games if we have no internet. Some Pros and ConsPros:- You get to have your own army - You are a king of an empire, many to choose from- Not laggy at all, even with a good computer- Very challenging, I consider this a good thing- Historical Characters in game- Historical Battles you can play- You get to play in custom battles, with OP(Over Powered) units.- 5 types of mods w/ Kingdoms expansion. (As of now, I think it comes just with base game.) Base Game, Americas, Crusades, Brittania, and Teutonic.Cons:- Bad Graphics (Im a texture kinda guy.)- Tends to bug out sometimes, its an old game.- Other Kingdoms may have an advantage over you in early game depending on their Pros and Cons (Says when you got to pick a kingdom)Overall, this game is really good. I love it so much, it would definetly recommend you get it right away. Although I have yet to play with my friends, its still fun playing by yourself.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2016
												Solid so far, pretty sure i have way more than 7 hours in, as I play offline mostly, idk if it counts those hours or not. Windows 10, AMD A10, Radeon R5, nothing fancy imo, basic little laptop from a "big box" store. A FEW crashes, standard "unspecified error" crash, which were all negated by aggressive game saving habits. I can not seem to duplicate the crash either; ie: during a 200+ turn campaign, it did the crash mid game but never did it again afterwards. Playing Vanilla game with the graphics turned down slightly from the "auto detect" settings to (maybe?) help minimize crashing lol. HAve not tried mods yet, but I am interested in them for sure. Gotta research which ones work well with the current steam version, as i just DL'd the game about a month ago. All in all the vanilla game (I bought the whole "Kingdoms Expansion bundle" to hopefully get the best version) runs GREAT, couple crashes, and personally I have not experienced ANY bugs or flaws that were game breaking. Again, this is exp on the Vanilla game from a TW vet who just recently got back into this series, playing at least 2 hours a day since I bought it.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												This could have been a great game... indeed many contend that it is. I disagree however, because my criteria for a great game includes controls that are not broken.Go on the internet and you will see legions of fanboys jumping through hoops to defend the obvious lazy programming and lack of anything even resembling QA testing that has resulted in controls so broken that even the simplest of maneuvers can reduce even normally patient gamers to shouting, fist-pounding emotional wrecks as they watch what should have been a gimme battle devolve into an embarrassing defeat simply due to the fact that it is next to impossible to get your troops to do as they are told.Fanboys respond to this by saying "you just have to learn how to micro it properly", or "maybe if you learned to do it properly..." blah blah blah, ad nauseum. I call shenanigans. I'm not talking about advanced maneuvers. Not even the cavalry charges. I'm talking about "you three units, go over here and stand in a line". Ten minutes later, they are still milling around where they were before, apparently totally defeated by the entrance to a city street. And now you're out of position, and your strategy collapses as your longbowmen are outflanked by the cavalry your spearmen were supposed to be defending against. There is no excuse for this. And if it isn't getting stuck on each other and milling around, it's running *past* the spot where you told them to go, triggering a battle you're not ready for and resulting in units routing and strategies failing. No excuse. Cavalry is similarly broken. You cannot have more than one unit of cavalry at a time, because one unit requires constant micromanagement just to charge properly. They have to be lined up *just so*, the enemy has to be clicked on *just so*, they have to be watched all the way to their target lest they encounter a tree or a slight rise and begin milling around in confusion, and they have to be told to retreat the instant they hit, or even the lowliest of peasants will begin to bowl them over like ninepins. If you can have more than one unit of cavalry in this game; never play it again because you can click fast enough to make money playing Starcraft professionally.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
												I played a bit before i linked up my retail key to Steam when i read up not long ago that when Gamespy started pushing up daisies, the key you got can be linked up to steam for a copy. Since i could no longer play the game because of some windows incompatibility with the DRM on the disc, i installed here and it works now.Having played a bit again, i remember now why i have not touched this game in a long time compared to Rome TW. Mostly to do with unit movement orders; Horses don't charge their enemies almost all the time. Ordering a unit of troops through an enemy gate, sometimes they go through and just stand in formation on the other side until you tell them to move again, when attacking a fleeing enemy some units stop following and stand around, some units on a wall or on the ground finished attacking an enemy and as you tell them to move they are still in fighting until you tell them to stop and move again and so on. It is one of the most annoying features on the game that i remember. i have lost a few fights because my forces spread out during fighting instead of charging in and attacking.Compared to Rome TW, this game has more features and looks better, but i would take Rome TW over this any day.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Medieval II: Total War is perhaps my favorite in the line of Total War games. Though it lacks some of the newer mechanics and complexities that are in the latest Total Wars, the game still stands out as having some of the most satisfying battles I have ever played. When I think Total War, I think Medieval II. The graphics still look great, and the gameplay still holds up.  I don't know why my steam account says I've only played a couple hours, because I have definitely sunk multiple lazy weekends into this game. If you love the more recent Total War games, give this one a shot, it is a step above the rest.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												I thought this was a GREAT game for the 2 days i played it... a good Medieval styled Rome Total War in my oppinion... for those who want a challenge, get this gamefor those who love Medieval times, get this gamefor those who hate Rome II Total War, get this gamefor those who love strategy, get this gamefor those who love Total War..... GET THIS GAME!!!ok, enough ♥♥♥♥in around, now this IS a near perfect game in my eyes so if this sounds biased... dont tear me up for it :/Ok well for 1 in my opinion this is 10x better than Rome II even though the graphicas arent excellent. And as i usually say to friends when i recomend this that the BEST thing about this game are the Events! The Events are TOTALLY the best part of this game, they can be GAME CHANGING things at time like when the Black Death hits and it when it did for me i ALMOST lost the game by losing my entire family tree, and also i ended up with 1 family member alive with no wife... Or when the the New World is discovered where you fight HORDES of Natives that outnumber you 10-1Now on to the thing EVERYONE does in MIITW, the battles, they are awesome, 9/10 because their are some glitches but its grandious Vs. say our latest Total War games... and also, heres something i know for a fact i might get♥♥♥♥♥♥for, THE DLC ACTUALLY ADDS TO THE ENTIRE GAME AND ITS NOT ♥♥♥♥♥ING LEVELS. Yeah... only 1 piece of DLC on this game.. and it adds a bunch of campaigns that are AWSOME and also it makes it possible for mods to change your game and make it look like a entirelly new one! For instence, i have Third Age Total War installed and i am IN LOVE with it! Now compared to newer mods for newer Total War's the MIITW mods actually CHANGE the game and add on instead of fixing it...Well thats my review, my rating of this game, well ill borrow Angry Joe's rating system and give this a 9/10, a LEGENDARY status and a MUST own, and i bet if he did review this, he would put the Badass Seal of Approval on this! Well thats all.

												The vanilla game is very entertaining. It will definitely provide hours of entertainment and no new game will ever be the same. Some downsides include; some troop types can feel very similar, some factions aren't able to get later technology (i.e, cannons, Arquebusier's), and the campaign does feel short in the long term.Overall, the default game is great, but some minor areas fall flat of the target, as most games do. 												An extraordinary classic that required me 72 hours of play to complete (full campaign).It's a game of years ago so it requires a lot of micromanagement but it's enjoyable to play if you are looking for an RTS that defined the genere on the PC.There are a couple of annoying things gameplay-wise (your merchants get put off business regularly by other merchants, and spies and assassins fail and die regardless of they mission success), but when you get a solid game economy, those problems become secondary.

												amazing game, best stragagy game series. The graphics my lack but that means that it works for non-gaming cpus which may benifit people that dont want to spend thousands of dollars on a high-end laptop or computer. 												If there was such thing as an "In the middle" choice, I'd choose that. You see, Med II is a very intersting girlfriend. I have never seen her before, but when I did see her I knew what I had to do. This girl was gorgeous! It was my ideal women, and when I finally mustered up the courage and bought her... stuff happened. She was great at first, but it was hard maintaining a relationship, mainly because she was a little old school in the graphics department, but she was happy at least. Then her A.I became very predictable, and despite numreous attempts at trying to make her a little bit more suprising I changed the difficulty and other settings that didn't help all to much. It came to the point where I was getting tired of the same old Med II, and then I forced her to get mods, specifically Third Age Divivde and Conquer.If you didn't understand any of that, than here it is in different wording. Med II is fun at first but the A.I gets very predictable and eventually either to easy or way too hard. A very good substitute for this is downloading the Divide and Conquer which is still being patched and made to this day (only thing is is that this is a Lord of the Rings mod).

content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												576 hours on record and I still have so much try on this game. It is in my opinion the ultimate strategy game and best of the Total War series. The main menu music and background instantly give you a taste of the grand scale and epic setting. Even compared to Rome 2 it is visually stunning and will run great on most newer systems, although I remember when it first came out it was brutally demanding of graphics power. One aspect that sets this game out from the others in the series is the religion factor. Yes, the other games have it also, but not to the lenghts of this game. Sending a massive crusading army across Europe and into the Middle East, and than being met by an opposing Jihad force is simply stunning. Than depending on the outcome of the crusade you will either be greatly rewarded by the church for victory, or for failure you may be excommunicated and cast as an enemy to the Christiandom! Another unique feature is the guilds. While their effects and purpose are hard to see at first, they will progressively become more helpful to your nation and will lead to some awesome and elite troops specific to different factions. For example, England can develop a woodsmen guild in Nottingham and once it reaches a certain level, you can recruit Sherwood archers that can camoflauge in the woods and have tremendous range. The powerful Knights Templar are another guild specific to Christian Nations, while eastern nations have the Hashassins guild. If there is one thing that frustrates me during combat, it is that sometimes archers don't fire directly at the enemy when there on walls, but it just takes some practice mastering their line of sight and taking advantage of their range. I also wish there were more historical battles as they provide some awesome scenerios and challenging battles. I recommend going through atleat one play through as the vanilla game, and than trying out the VAST amounts of full and partial mods that have been made for this game. You can even try your own costumizations to the script and combinations of different modification until you find the perfect balance for you. All in all, this a game for the ages and is better than 99% of the garbage that comes out nowadays. 9.8/10

content:
Posted: April 21, 2016
												Total War is a great series that you should really get into, Medieval 2 Total War is the game that will get you into the Total War series I have recommended this game to countless people and most if not all of them have thanked me for it while some games like Attila are pricey they still deliver the experience of being in a battle.Medieval 2 Total War is one of the best strategy games I have ever played, it's simple to understand interface and mechanics are very effective when it comes to cramming them into one small easy to access UI.You can have fun by playing the expansive campaign to conquer Europe and the middle-east or play a historical battle that actually happened hundreds of years ago or create your own battle with your choice of map armies and roster. You can even spice your game up a bit by installing mods (you will probably need the Kingdoms DLC to do so) onto your computer, like Third Age or The Elder Scrolls Total War, to say that this game was released in 2006 Creative Assembly have done a great job making this game.Gameplay is simple: build an army, attack a castle, expand your kingdom, WIN, but where this game really shines is in the battles themselves have up to a maximum of 24,000 soldiers on the battlefield and witness the true bloody history of Medieval battles.The downside of this game are the graphics although they are playable the fact that the game was released in 2006 tells us that the graphics aren't going to be as good as other Total War games, you'll know what I mean if you compare the graphics to Total War: Attila.KIMBOF1's Score = 5/5Yes the graphics are a bit rubbish but you kinda forget about them when your deeply immersed in the heat of a battle.

content:
Posted: January 16
												If there was such thing as an "In the middle" choice, I'd choose that. You see, Med II is a very intersting girlfriend. I have never seen her before, but when I did see her I knew what I had to do. This girl was gorgeous! It was my ideal women, and when I finally mustered up the courage and bought her... stuff happened. She was great at first, but it was hard maintaining a relationship, mainly because she was a little old school in the graphics department, but she was happy at least. Then her A.I became very predictable, and despite numreous attempts at trying to make her a little bit more suprising I changed the difficulty and other settings that didn't help all to much. It came to the point where I was getting tired of the same old Med II, and then I forced her to get mods, specifically Third Age Divivde and Conquer.If you didn't understand any of that, than here it is in different wording. Med II is fun at first but the A.I gets very predictable and eventually either to easy or way too hard. A very good substitute for this is downloading the Divide and Conquer which is still being patched and made to this day (only thing is is that this is a Lord of the Rings mod).

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Don't let my hours fool you. I have easily clocked in 1000 hours into this game in the past half decade on the cd version of the game. This is MY favorite of all total war games. I was about 12 or 13 when I started playing this and kept playing this until I graduated from high school. I've played every faction, played many mods, and thoroughly played the Kingdoms campaigns. My favorite campaign being the Crusades and Americas. I used to cheat on all my campaigns when it got rough when I was younger but as I grew up I learned that playing without cheats made this game a hell a lot funner. Being forced to fight with a single stack army against the 4 stacks the cheating ai mustered in just a few turns lead towards very fun and epic battles. Battles mostly won by me of course. ;P Although it's not as advanced and glamourous as the new total war games(Shogun2 is pretty fantastic too), it definitely earned its spot as one of the best total war games out there. I easily recommend this to Strategy players.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2016
												I am not a competent or experienced gamer, but even I can appreciate the scope and texture of this game as compared to Rome II. The battle maps are exensive and intuitive when it comes to tactics. The faction rosters are exquisitely detailed. One great thing about this game is the extent to which it's as hard as you want it to be. If you feel like getting your backside handed to you, turn all the advice off and jump in at medium difficulty or above. If, like me, you're a little more timid, start with low difficulty, start with the advice turned on and, if in doubt, turn to youtube or similar for advice. Swissman15, Pixelatedapollo and many others have huge numbers of instructional and demo videos which can tell you useful things, like how to make enemies rout, how to make the best of itwhen you've got vastly superior or inferior troops in one area, what to do about hills and so forthYou can make this a 40-hours-a-run strategy game, a 20 minute hit-and-run tactics game, an RPG of sorts, go achievement hunting... the choice is yours.

												Played this game quite a bit before I activated it through Steam.This game is awesome and I love it but one thing that irks me is that you cannot train like 5 units of the same type in the same province because of limitations which although I do agree that this is accurate during the timeframe (you aren't just going to be able to raise an army of noble knights repeatedly) makes sense, it irks me.Besides me being irked from that, it's a great game. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
												Second best Total War title to date, second only to Rome 1. Only thing that makes it worse is the Castle/City feature, where each settlement is divided into two categories: Castles and Cities. Castles are obviously hard to attack, having up to 3 layers of walls, and recruit much better units. They are poor for getting money or raising population, you can't even set taxes to the castles. Cities recruit worse units (though depending on your faction sometimes the city parts are better than their castle counterparts, Italian Spear Milita and Venetian/Genoean Crossbowmen being examples of this) but are so much better for economy. Most of the time your armies will be composed of units that can only be recruited in castles, but if you take a city with it and lose a lot of troops there is no way to replenish them unless you send them to another castle. That is literally my only gripe with this game. Graphics still kind of hold up, even 9 (holy♥♥♥♥♥♥this game is 9 years old?!?!) years later. Massive scale armies are often seen, the AI isn't entirely stupid and can be logical in their choices after you think hard enough. There is a stereotype (much like Civ V) that the AI will randomly attack you for no reason, but there are always logical reasons. Either they see you as weak and easy pickings, you are attacking (and beating) one of their allies, or you've taken lands that they wanted. If you really want to avoid war with a certain faction, just avoid those three things. The game can be challenging at times, often times you will think you've won a war and then suddenly they have a full army besieging your capital, that carefully hid in the forests so you couldn't see them. The economy isn't as challenging as I'd like it to be, you can simply raise taxes as high as you can without having the happiness go below 100% (Yea for some reason the happiness can go well over 100%, it's weird) and don't garrison your cities with expensive units. As long as you're using your armies to conquer cities you'll never go into the red. The game is challenging and interesting, no two campaigns will ever be the same. A lot of things are predictable, such as for me Milan always seems to be a huge power that gobbles up France and the Holy Roman Empire with ease, and Egypt always ends up winning in the east unless the Mongols decide to head that direction (they always beeline straight for Poland/Hungary/Russia in my games and get destroyed by knights). There are in game events such as the Mongol invasion, the Black Death, the Timurid invasion, Gunpowder being invented, and you can even travel to the New World late in the game. You will quickly learn to love and hate some factions, personally I hate fighting any italian faction just because their Italian Spear Militia are rediculous and their crossbowmen do waaay too much damage without taking much in return. Overall the game is a 9,9/10 for me. It's my second favorite strategy game of all time, and there is a still active modding community that can spice up your games should you ever get bored of the same map/factions. Definetly worth the 20$, but you'll often find it on sale for much less. The DLC is definetly worth at least a try, it adds 4 new campaigns (different maps and factions, it doesn't add anything to the main game they're basically 4 smaller standalone games) which are pretty fun but a tad bit small and limited, which is to be expected given how small the regions are. If you liked any other Total War game or are interested in buying one to see if you do like it, definetly buy either this one or Rome 1 first.

content:
Posted: February 17
												Very good :)The game is awesome however there are a few bugs that need fixing like in sieges sometimes units would just stand on walls not attacking nor routing once their broken(This only happens with the AI on Huge scale armies). That's the only problem I have with combat against AI. Medieval 2 is a great game but there are some things that can be improved like making the units more unique because it looks weird seeing the same unit over and over again even though they're called english knights but they look the same as french nobles just with different colors and flags. Some factions have very similar colors so it can get confusing when the french and the portuguese go head to head on a battlefield. I know that's the reason why the banners are there but they dont really help when you're trying to watch the heat of battle and you dont know who's fighting.the campaign difficulty of the AI is great and is very challenging although when it comes to the battle difficulty it's lacking a little bit.It would also be great if the islamic factions would be buffed and the mongols and timurids would be playable factions because there are on 3 playable islamic factions in the game and they're all too similar.I just wish that every faction offers a different playstyle that I can adjust to. It makes the game more challenging and less repetitive if I have to change the way I plan.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												Heres why you should buy an play this gameIts cheap , and the stories it creates through gameplay. All I have to do is write about a battle I had in my latest Campaign as France.So I was fighting a battle against the English, these ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s had to gual to stab me in the back while I was off fighting the Moor's in Spain, they laid siege to Paris. What I did was raise a small army of elite soldiers coupled with peseants and drove back there full stack army. I chased them back towards there motherland, then they decided to send ANOTHER army to back them up that was roughly half a stack, I shrugged since the combined force I had gotten from Paris was about 1 and a half stacks of troops, not only that I had feudal knights and armored swordsmen.So I started the battle and decimated the first enemy wave, not even the english Billmen could not stop my swordsmen charge, and my feudal knights broke whatever resistance was left. I had taken a decent amount of casualties, my feudal knights were a bit poorly managed and took alot of casualties and my peseants took a beating. So I reform and prepare to face the 2nd english army, the full one. What I had realized is that this full army was not a pushover, it was composed of fuedal knights, lowbowmen and even armoured swordsmen, AND EVEN ARTILLERY. I quickly matched his front line, charged and flanked with cavalry, his artillery killed over 100 men before I managed to hit it with one of my feudal knights, then I turn them unto the enemy flank just in the knick of time to prevent my men from routing, I have my general rally as well to make sure my men chase the enemy down. Once back on the campaign map, I ransom the men I captured back to england for 7,500 gold (which is alot at turn 45)other things; ♥♥♥♥ the pope if you have more than 10 regions, unlike Crusader Kings 2 there is no official way to fight factions that are christian as a christian, even if enemies are the agressor they get a free pass to ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥up on you while you will get commands from the pope with threat of excommunication, which is pretty bad place to be in btw.Also, this is a great mod platform. There is a LORD OF THE RINGS MOD that is amazing, as well as a Game of Thrones mod, and many more total conversions as well as basic modifications like overhauls to the game.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19
												Read this very carefuly,please!This game is fantastic when it comes to gameplay.You can read a ton of positive reviews on here,but I can't recommend this game to you if you want to play multiplayer,because it's simply 0 fun.The mechanics are there,you can play against players like you can against AI but the performance,to put it frankly,is DREADFUL.Once you get 3000-4000 units on the battlefield the game ♥♥♥♥♥ itself.You can run it at good fps with whatever your specs are,but the units just move for 0.1sec then stop for 0,3 sec and you barely get anything done!I had the displeasure of playing a siege battle 3vs2 and just destroying the walls and getting our men through took 1h30min , I'm not joking.The whole battlefield looked like a Win 98 trying to run CS GO.By the time the walls of the Castle were destroyed all fun had crumbled with them and there was immense frustration on both parties,that soon turned into a chat war for the simplest of things .. the game started with friendly attidude and the frustration from the wasted time turned into toxicity in seconds.As far as I know this is an issue with other Total War titles as well.Get this game if you want the amazing single player experience.Do NOT waste your money for this game's multiplayer,because its unplayable. The only matches that work properly are 1v1s with less than 3000-4000 troops on the battlefield.Beyond that it's a spastic freakshow of swordmen,bowmen and pikemen suffering from Parkinsons' ...

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
												From this to Rome2/Atilla in ten years.When you come back and play this after playing the other two its hard to say that the series has improved. Graphically at least in combat ME2 looks almost as good as the others and everything else they have added in the other 2 such as agents and settlement development has been poor. Ten years and I'm still playing better mods on ME2 than the vanilla and even some mods on the other 2 combined. As much as I want Total War Warhammer too it just doesnt look that good to pay full price for.......seems the only way to play Total War is wait for the sales a year later and as this shows they dont change much for the better over the years so why not wait.As for ME2 in its day it was the Best and even now its still Great and you could easily argue as good as if not better than most of the recent Total War products...........and back in those days they used to release complete games with a worth while expansion pack.

number of helpful: 6 of 22 people (27%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
												Ok. I'm giving this one the thumbs down because there are better TW games on the market that you should buy.Yes,  I have tons of hours on medieval II. Yes, I think it's a good game. But that's because I'm:1. A MASSIVE TW FAN2. A MASSIVE FAN OF THIS TIME PERIODSo for me, I'm probably adding 3 extra points on the scale out of 10 than a regular RTS/G.S. gamer will.Now then, I want to talk about a few things here:1. AI is BAD- - - 1.a. Campaign AI:Sometimes factions will go to war with you just because. This is a problem because weak factions will go to war with you, and then they will ask for a peace treaty. You can really game the system because you can demand money as part of the peace treaty. Soooooooo a weak faction goes to war with you and then pays you money to stop the war. That's a problem.Also, the game throws stacks at you without generals. That means those stacks always lose if you have a general.- - - 1.b. Battle AI:Battle AI is generally bad for a few reasons. [1] The game mixes unit types in armies, but some of the unit types are super weak. Specifically archers/siege units are very weak in field battles. But sometimes the AI will have a lot of ranged/siege units and just attack you even though it has no chance of winning. [2] The AI doesn't try and use the battle field terrain. You can easily manipulate the AI to give up the high ground. Also, chain routing is easy to do in this TW game, so the AI will almost always chain route if you flank properly. 2. Game doesn't make sense!Say you play Scotland. You become an ally of England. England betrays your alliance and goes to war with you. The Pope gets MAD AT YOU because you're fighting England, which is a Christian faction. So the AI goes to war with you and then gets mad at you because you're at war! 3. Rebellions/enemy agents show up just because.You can have a conetent city and a rebel army just shows up. You can have a territory that's mostly your faction's religion and an evil witch/priest will show up just because. If you set campaign difficulty to max difficulty this will happen. I understand that "very hard" should be very hard.... but to get rebellions when the territories are content just doesn't make sense and seems to be something they put into the game to justify the "very hard" difficulty setting.4. You can't customize generals.Generals will generate their own traits as they live. Sometimes the traits are useful, sometimes not so much. You don't really have control over any of this. You could make a general fight in a bunch of battles and he will naturally gain command, but you can't fine tune your generals to fit very specific roles.5. Generals die quickly.You progress through the years quickly. This is kinda sucks because you usually lose your faction leader in the early part of your game due to how old he is. Characters age quickly, so you can't get too attached to generals or use them for a very long period of time like you can in TW games like Shogun 2 - where you can use your faction leader for the entire game! This kind of makes sense because you start off in the Medieval era and your late game units are early rifle units, so it would make sense for you to burn through a few generations before you got to the late game.6. Ranged units are usually not good (not including rifles).Archers are either useful or terrible. They're useful for using fire arrows as a moral shock/setting siege engines on fire. But, they do almost no damage to enemy units. So you're always better off trying to flank an enemy army and causing it to route rather than use ranked units. In defense, a few ranged units are OK, but overall archers just aren't that great in this version of TW with the exception of a few.If Medieval II is on sale, yeah - give it a try. But if you're interested in TW and want a solid game I highly recommend Shogun 2. The AI is good, the combat is good, and the game is frequently on sale, as well as FOTS.Overall, I love Medieval II, but there are so many other better, more polished, modern Total War games you can buy and enjoy. I only recommend this game to people who are old time Total war fans like myself, or if you want to visit an older title.

content:
Posted: January 4
												I'd heard about this game when I got into shogun 2 and I really wanted to like it but after playing shogun 2 it just isn't tolerable.The camera is painfully clunky and hard to control. It's not intuitive in the slightest and I found myself constantly having to pause just to readjust the camera so I could see what was going on.The units don't follow your commands very well, especially in seige battles, they won't form up they wander off, they go down ladders despite being set to stand guard. It's like trying to keep track of a small child in a zoo and it's just as frustrating.In the deployment phase there are areas your men should be able to stand where they simply won't do it. no explanation they just refuse to be placed where you want them. It's especially irritating when one guy of an enemy troop gets past your front line and ALL of your archers in a unit stop shooting just to fight that one guy. Speaking of archers that hand red line from Shogun 2 that tells you when you are in range? yeah that's gone you have no way of knowing just how far archers can fire and I see them constantly shooting into walls and at things they can't hit wasting tons of their ammo and doing nothing.The enemy AI is dumb as a rock, they ignore gates and funnel themselves into choke points making it really easy to win battles even when outnumbered.Overall the game feels dated and clunky especially when compared to the newer titles. I really wanted to like this game but at this point I'm 90% sure that this game's reputation comes from a nostalgic fan base and not from any real quality of the game. I'm sure it was good for it's time but considering the improvements in later games it just doesn't hold up well over time.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												The game is acutally OK, its not too bad, its just really realy dated... bug-wise.It seems that everything sega touches is either buggy or broken. The game has serious pathfinding problems, and the units respond strangely on the battlefield. All-in-all the battles aren't worth it, its just very predictable or downright broken.All the other aspects are ok, the graphics the sound, the presentation, its a big brand game, but it doesn't deliver really. The game pretends to be big, but its actually really, really small. And there aren't that many countries to play with, even if you count the entire map. It reminds me of Lords of the Realm 3 and how that sucked big time, but maybe I'm just spoiled by Paradox Interactive. The campain map is limiting in most ways, and the gameplay its self either has things that dont realy work for it, or that you can simply completely ignore.Maybe if this was all there was to it, ok, it could have been good... But we have Civilization 4, Europa Universalis 4 and many other real grand strategy games out there.Heck even Zeus: Master of Olympus is better than this.Big dissapointment, don't buy unless you are a TW fanatic.The game is much better/prettier/bigger if you install the Stainless Steal mod, so if you do buy it, get the mod asap.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2016
												I've always thought Medieval II was rather bad, but after trying out newer, better Total Wars, I've discovered that Medieval II must be the worst game in the entire series. Don't get me wrong, this game would have been great if it weren't for the many oversights and bugs in it. The campaign map, meh, could be better with the AI and stuff. But what really gets to me is the ridiculously poorly made battle map. For starters, it takes ages for artillery units to prepare to fire. Imagine it, the enemy infantry is coming, and you have ballistas or later in the game, cannons, ready to fire when they get within range. The enemy is in range, but you notice that your artillery batteries aren't firing, you zoom in and it's because one guy is taking a seizure trying to get into the right position to load the artillery, when the guy should already be in position, and the artillery loaded anyway.And who the hell designed the UI? I've had this game for 2 years on Steam, and many years on CD before that, and it was only recently I learnt what I could really do on the campaign map. Due the the poor combat AI, battles are extremely unrealistic, whether it's two soldiers fighting eachother, or four armies. This is mainly because it takes hours for soldiers to do a 90 degrees turn due to the poor animations. What happened to the diplomacy? Why use "diplomats" on the campaign map? You should be able to contact any nation at any time. As far as I know, kings don't simply run out of diplomats. It certainly doesn't take years for them to reach another country either.Every problem I've listed here is about 10% of all problems in this game. Don't waste your money here. Total War is brilliant, just not this one. Creative Assembly, if you're reading this, please create a Medieval III so we can enjoy Total War in that time period without all of the bugs and problems. Thank you.Update: The real reason the Spanish Tercio formation failed was because in every instance, the musketeers refused to go back inside the pike square, because they were like: "No, we're going to get ourselves killed so you lose the battle" - And the ones who did actually go inside the square walked, despite being told to run, and unfortunately, they got run down by the enemy general's bodyguard, who, for some reason, risked his life even though he could defeat me with the bugs alone, despite the fact my army has superior training, equipment, and a tercio formation which doesn't even work.I see many people disagree with me, can somebody open up a conversation in the comments here? Because am I the only one here who has these problems with this game?

content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												I had played it a long time ago. I was recently confined to an older machine, and, being unable to play a newer TW game, I bought it on steam to replay. I was very disappointed to find it in this sorry state. At its heart, this game is as good a TW game as any, but at the same time it is thoroughly broken. I remembered this game being far from perfect, but I didn't remember it being nearly unplayable.There are many things I could mention, from disappearing units to the inexcusable lack of colour coordination of the menus. But the one thing that will really send you looking for a different TW title is the pathfinding. There's no way I can list all the things that go wrong. If you can think of it, it happens here. Ignoring commands? Sure. Spontaneously cancelling orders? Of course. Long ant-lines when turning corners? Always. How about a unit splitting into two parts that move at different speeds? How about one bugged guy sprinting in place causing your entire unit to become tired? You didn't think of that did you? Play this game and you'll learn all about broken pathfinding. Every decision you make needs to be explained to your units an average of 3 times, and, once it's working, you don't touch the unit or you'll ruin everything.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												A wargame of an exagerated fame. Decent graphics and with the good mechanics of Total Wars series, but thats is all. Maybe its wonderful for multiplayer mode, but in single player mode, the AI is cheater and treacherous: all are against the player; the enemies generate more units per turn, they come from far away left helpless his own territories to attack you, the diplomatic system is expensive, alliances are unstable and unrealistic historically...If you have played intensively the game and considerate this opinion exagerated, try with Bizantine Empire in normal level, and see what happens after turn 50 or 70...  The game breaks his own rules, and the factions shall attack to you without any diplomatic or strategic logic.There are many examples: the eastern hordes can ignore nearest, poorest or helpless factions only to search, sack or take your cities; a faction with only have one city, and no allies, can mantain two armies with expensive units, over his economic capacity; a great faction suddenly attacks you with all of his power, and soon collapses because no protect his rearguard, conquered by a lesser faction...There are a better wargame of historical medieval theme, called Kinights of Honor, that was published years before, with a more honest IA and a deeper mechanics.

												can i recommend a game where the devs has focused on mainly historic theme and feeling and forgotten all about balancing and general balanced gameplay? yes and no.When this game performs at it's best, you'll feel like a midieval commander taunting banter at your foes while you cavalry tramples them to death.Grand Campaign:like most total war games, the grand campaign is pretty straight forward. you have the tactical turn based map with figures representing armies, moving arround doing what you command them to. the build menu isn't too diffrerent if you played Rome Total war.what annoys me however is that there are a huge lack of political statistics. you never know who is on the edge to being agressive towards you because all you get is a welcomed enemy, or neutral. doesn't really tell you alot.another problem is that once you begun building up the begining of your empire, you would have to deal with the fact that 60% of your neighbourghs will almost instantly be hostile towards you, either by sending a ton of agents or simply entering an all out war with you.so now you are locked in a massive war that forces you to stay defensive for 50 turns and not expand in any way. if just one of your armies move the slightest amount towards an enemy stronghold, then they will just completely ignore the danger you put them in and attack you city. this will ultimately lead you in loop where you are stuck reclaiming and taking cities and using all of your Florins (the currecny ingame) to replenish your troops.the worst part about these wars is that a lot of the times where you ahve the advantages in unit type, strenght and numbers it can still lead to some of the nastiest possibilities you can get. expect an army of 240 knights, 80 militia and 45 archers wot win against 400 spear militia, 100 knights and a bombard? NOPEyou have the stronger units that counters the enemy in every way, but for some reason that game won't allow you to have fun and win the battles in a fair way. the reason why is simply due to the fact that some of these engages magicly halves your army so instead of having an attacking army of 350-400 you suddenly only have 250. this happened regularly and the worst part was the aftermath. because a defending army in the city was joined in, i automaticly lost the city after. this wouldn't have been so bad if the amount of troops i lost was under half of my army, but yet for some reason half of the half that didn't die was mysteriesly dispanded instead of going into the castle again.this wasn't just a one time fluke. it happened many times and not only for sieges. on top of these ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t battles you also run in to the fact that the enemies tend to get high end units atleast 30 turns before you do. which means that when you just got longbowmen as the brits, you are already fighting feudal knights which absolutely wreck everything you can muster at this point.now we get into multiplayer:in short a huge dislike from me about the multiplayer battles you can have.remember how broken a pike wall was in the first Rome total war? double that and you have a musket army or a crossbow army. unless you place your entire army furthest back you can, you will get attacked just after your spawn due to their overly high range. not only does crossbows have an incredible range (even outranging longbows) but also a decent firering speed, ammo capacity, accuracy and worst of all a cheap price. i made a high tech army of knights on foot and cavalry and a decent amount of cannon fodder and had almost 1000 more men that my friend (oponent) had.what he had was unfortunately 4 squads of militia crossbows. all i could see the first 2 minutes was piles after piles of dead knights and cannon fodder whilst i desperately tried to rush his crossbows to minimize damage. but when my army was locked in melee with his entire army it was too late. his crossbows had done the job and weakened my squads immensely.TL:DRDon't ever invest in this game if you want a decent game to play with and against friends and can't handle rage inducing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.Authers note:This game has done what is impossible for 99% of all my games. it made me utterly violent to my environment out of pure rage over it's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.

number of helpful: 8 of 31 people (26%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
												I've been playing the total war games since the original and even though they all had bugs and issues I loved them none the less. Then when Medieval total war 2 was first released I bought that as well but it had more bugs than all other total war games combined and so I quickly stopped playing it.Fast pace 9 years forward and low and behold, it was on a steam sale and so I bought it again. I wish I hadn't though!My god I wish I hadn't! This game is broken in every way imaginable! I don't remember it being this bad. If I had a hard corpy I would break the cd and mail it to the developers with a note that said, fix me, I'm broken!Pro's:It was cheapThe strategy part is funCon'sUnit placement is impossible. I literally timed how long it took me to get one unit to accept the placement. I gave up!Placing Archers unit on walls makes the archers shoot up into the air instead of down at the enemy.Moving units down from the walls is impossible. See Unit placement issues above.Moving units away from imcomming enemy units has to be done an hour in advance. It doesn't respond. Takes about 10 seconds before units move after given orders. Cavalry units that are discribed as ruling the battlefield gets owned by peasants.Placing stakes in front of your own units to protect from enemy cavalry is great until you have to move your own cavalry. No matter how much space there is around the stakes. They go right through it I die.The automated battle option is completely random.Screen randomly decides to get stuck moving in one direction all the god danm time. unable to move the camera back save & load is what you'll be doing most of.I cannot recommend this game. Even if it was on a 99 cent sale I would not recommend it. Maybe they patched it wrong or whatever, but this is completely ridiculus. The game is broken and still it is being sold here.

Posted: June 28, 2015
												I'm sorry I guess I'm spoiled by the newer TW games; but I just can't find myself enjoying this game. The AI pathfinding is clunky and buggy, camera controls is outdated and slow. Combat is a hair-tearing affair as my units need to be told REPEATEDLY to attack an enemy right in front of them before they actually get the message. I'm playing the crusader campaign and without disabling FOW via console, the mission to send a diplomatic envoy to any unmet player is a headache as none but their capital city is shown on the unexplored terrain. That and the lack of showing roads/pathways on the map untill you're right on them could mean your diplomats are taking one heck of a scenic route as you're blindly wandering the earth hoping to bump into a city to make contact with.Yes I know this is an old as hell game, and for it's time it may have been good. But now? Get this only if you're in it for the nostalgia or just someone who wants ALL the TW games to date.

number of helpful: 5 of 25 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												Same game as the first Rome Total War. Just the map and the units changed and a few little things added.The good thing of this game: The awesome game concept. The same thing that Creative Assembly have been squeezing since the first Shogun: Total War.The BAD things: Buggy as hell, terrible unit pathfinding, painful interface.And, the most important, ZERO AI. Seriously, this is inexcusable in a strategy game, or in something that pretends to be an strategy game.  You can literally crush overwhelming enemy armies in the hardest level of the game, just because the computer is TOTALLY STUPID. Even with all the cheats the computer does, the game can be easily beaten in the very hard levels.  The sad thing is that it seems that CA is not interested on improving the AI, as the only thing that gets better in each new Total War game are the graphics. Maybe they should create a new genre ("Casual Strategy") to include all the Total War series.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												This game is such a great concept. A no brainer, really. So whats the problem with every game in this franchise? The A.I. is also a no brainer. There is no challenge short of the lazy, overwhelm the player situation. Which is still hard since I just fought one of my armys ( around 1k troops) againts three seperate armies with 2x my numbers. I wish I could say it was because I made some impossible move that won the day. (it WAS a tough fight, toughest I have seen so far) I didn't do anything smart. I did the only thing I could do to win. Pelted the A.I from far away until they gave me no choice but to engage them. once routed, I pulled my forces back, remorfed my lines and repeated. 2 other armys form into this and it becomes more of a timing game.Right after this, I go to defend a castle under siege. The problem? EVERY TIME the computer attacks my castles, they just sit there. 100% of the time I had to go after them. At best, I can send out 1 calvalry unit to gode them into doing something, but that rarely works. They siege my castle, I have to leave the castle and go after them. yay...I would sum up the Total War fanchise as follows: great ideas, HORRIBLE execution. NONE of it matters if the computer can't at least attack you during THEIR invasion of your territory. Everything else could be prefection, but with an A.I. that does little more then shuffle it's troops around, it wouldn't matter. I hate to say it, but stay clear of the entire franchise until a new game is released that shows an A.I. I couldn't trick into drowning itself. :(

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												Wow... I still remember many night hours spent with Medieval I and how much I enjoyed it... So, naturally I was pretty excited to try Medieval II...But... No 1440x900 resolution (at least I couldn't find it)... Ok, nothing too bad, will survive without everything looking perfect... Every other time I started the game, cursor location and click location were not aligned... Very frustrating... But, then again, ok, you get used to it, and it's a slow game...And, I started playing... With England... France attacked me, I started to conquer their cities, after which pope was angry... I tried to sign the white peace, and they declined... Ok, so I just conquered a few of your cities, my army is much larger then yours, and you are declining WHITE PEACE?! They attacked my army, pope excomunicated me (?!)... I conquered few of his cities, pope died, I was back in church again, new pope angry because of war, tried to sign the white peace, again... they declined (ok, suicidal idiots, I understand)... Spain allied with France, they attack, too... Try to sign peace with them, white peace, me giving tribute, they decline... Conquer 2 of their cities, and offer them all my money to sign peace, they decline...  Went "I don't give a ♥♥♥♥"... started destroying France, and left them with 1 city... They declined White Peace again... Game is starting to be extremely funny... Ok, trying to bribe french and spanish small armies, they usually decline, or take enormous amounts of money for a 2-3 units... Not important, anyway... I attack French last city... My enormous army is crossing the bridge, they are bribed... All of them... Ok, I have another one in vicinity, will attack with them while I gather more troops... They cross the bridge and are bribed... By whom!? How?! What the ♥♥♥♥ is wrong with that river?!So, this is the most annoying thing that happened... There were more small things... Much more... On the other hand, I understand that people will like the battle parts of this game, and I cannot say too many things about it, because I don't play it...I hate this game... it's definitely the worst strategy game I have ever played... Buy Knights of Honor if you want something similar but good (not just good, it's a great)... Of course, I can always recommend Crusader Kings II, as one of the best games ever made...

												I just can't get the thing about TW series. The first Shogun I played for a while when it came out was fun, but sequels are just jarringly boring. The strategy aspect of the game is just uninteresting and has no impact on anything you do. You will develop every city in the same way, stack a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of units, assasinate the enemy army leader and enter the battle and winning via circling bumblingly unable AI troops. After few historical battles and after a while in the grand campaign I gave up. If I want to play strategy, I will play EU4 or any other Paradox game.As to battle layer of the game, Cossacks 2 are so much better and go actually beyond "flank the enemy and masturbate" than any of the TW game (I don't know about Shogun 2 though). There's nothing more depressing than 4 soldiers fight while the rest just stand there waiting for their turn.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												Medieval 2 was probably the biggest dissapointment in the Total War series for me personally. Certain aspects of the game just really didn't fit in, like the castle/town conversion and just the feel of combat in general was a huge turnoff for me. It just feels like they wanted to add in some new features, but it ended up being poorly executed and unnecessary in the long run. Mods help improve the experience quite a lot, but the game simply wasn't as fun as other Total War games.

number of helpful: 3 of 30 people (10%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 25
												This has got to be the worst installment of the Total War series ever. As a massive fan of the series, his game really ruined the whole experience for me. The AI is atrocious, the units feel like empty sock puppets that never actually contact the enemy and just play their own dumb animations, they move so slowly that most of the time im playing it on 6X speed for any progress to be made. The AI, oh my. All your units have the IQ and memory span of a Dory fish, meaning they will obey your command for about 6 seconds, then abruptly stop for no apparent reason. I have to keep furiously clicking on an enemy unit for them to actually continue attacking/pursuing. The game, especially the combat just doesnt have a solid feel, its like playing with paper if you know what i mean. There are also stability issues, meaning it will freeze every few hours or so, this is very annoying. With more than 800 hours into the total war series (both on this computer and my old one), i cannot recommend this game. If you must, but it at 90% off. Thats all its worth.Edit - lol at all these fanboys attacking me. I learned a long time ago to ignore people of lesser intellect and to do/say what i want. Thats how i made my fortune, and thats why im fully retired before 30.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												Limitless replay value. My favorite of all TW games, I've found the AI works best with campaign difficulty set to Hard (this prevents AI from stacking tons of siege weapons) and battles set to Very Hard. There are plenty of mods but not integrated to steam workshop like the newer TW games, but worth giving a try. It's essentially Civ without map tiles, and battles are fought on landscapes generated mirroring the world map (i.e. If you are near/on a mountain or forest, that battlefield is going to have steep slopes or heavy foliage respectively) which works well, as most open field battles never feel the same. Sieges of towns and cities share similar layouts, however there is the opportunity to siege settlements a variety of ways: ladders, siege ram, siege towers, Spy infiltration, various siege units i.e Trebuchets, Catapults, Ballistae, Cannons.

												Medieval II Total War is a RTS (real time sratergy) of sorts that lets you play as one of the medieval super powers of that age, each with their own strengths and weaknesses.For example France has the best knights in the game but suffers when it comes to infantry whether they be archers or spear men. But England has worse knights but better foot soldiers.When starting the game the player has a number of options (besides the options menu and quiting the game of course). I have not covered  multiplayer in this review as I have no idea if any of the public servers work as I have never tried any of them,  but the single player,  oh boy i can tell you,  that it is good.First off the game gives you a custom battle mode. So, if you ever wondered what it would be like to have an army of nothing but peasants charge a fully equipped renaissance castle filled to the brim with archers with flaming arows, now you can find out!Then there's the campaign which might be confusing to some, but I suggest either looking up some hints and tips on the forums or replaying the tutorial. The campaign also has diplomacy, and very good diplomacy at that. And the best part is, the A.I does make deals with you that are in your favour, such as giving you gold or line of sight to where they live if you ally with them. As well as that there are spies for taking a peek at what your foes are doing and how big a force they have, as well as assasins for when you just need to go all stabby, stabby on that certain duke or king.Even though the graphics are not up to date whith what todays graphics are, they still look good even if you zoom right in on people's faces.That, and the way a castle looks when you bring its walls down with everyone on top falling through the new hole you just made, is awsome.The game also involves a lot of strategy. I can tell. And even if you sort of suck at it, like I do, you can still have a lot of fun witth this game. Basic tactics (allthough not as good) can still win you the game, at least against the medium A.I. as charging your entire hourse-back army down a hill to smash into your foe's unprotected rear is a tactic.Also, this game handles flaming projectiles really well, as hitting your enemy's peasants feels really satisfying, as well as making you really glad that you are not one of  those poor fools. This goes for catapults and trebuchets as well, exept bigger and much more deadly ones. You can also make enemy siege weapons burn down, which makes you feel like such a troll to the stupid A.I.  As you say "nope!" as your archers burn down an entire siege tower and the men who were just using it are forced to use ladders, only to be poked to death by your spear-men, now waiting at the top for them.So, all in all, I give it a 9/10 as there are some things that bug me a little, such as 1 guy with a leather shield blocking 10 arrows at once or a knight in full plate-mail bursting into flames at the first fire arrow.

												1) Start a game without Tutorial as Engliand2) Subdue all rebels on the isle3) Scot got angry with a bit spying and declare war, but they were my next target anyway4) Catch Edinburge off guard and its best general & army turned rebel and was soon crushed5) Try to be a good neighbour and quietly buide the Kingdom while building Watch Tower to get sight around the place6) Subdued a rebel city near France border and learnt that it was apparently theirs somehow.7) France invade without so much as giving a warning; trying to lay seign to a mainland fortress8) They were crushed and I retaliated by capturing theirs.9) Pope got angry; got excommunicated, but soon reconciled anyway. However Papal State seem determined to take France side by forcing me to make peace with them (unsuccessfully too since they're stubborn ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥)10) Annoyed with Popes, so assassins were sent to keep killing them (Yes plural!!) while making gain in France territory.11) Holy War against Cairo Declared and I was forced to take part in the campaign, so I gathered knights and Bowmans on the isle and made way downward. Somewhere along the way, Cairo got captured by Pole, so hey it's better this way, and I turned to France instead; keep killing French till they had one city left.12) Holy Roman Empire annoyed I try to eliminate her best friend, so she declared war, her army quickly repelled while Mongol invasion plagued the Eastern EU and the England was safely guarded behind the front line.13) Oh lucky number 13, I'll set sight on everything that's HOLY. First pillage Rome and sack Papal City. Second, Crushed the Holy Roman Empire while gaining friends in Dense, Morese, and Milan.To glory!Update 29 Nov, 2015With the entirety of Western Europe in the Great England's clutch; stretching from Scotland to Florence and from the edge of Southern Mediteranian Sea to the border of near-collapse Poland,Great English spreaded out to confront ever-growing menace of Mongol while at the same time confronting Jihadists Muslim at the heart of Holy Land Jerusalem. Friendship between Papalcy and England grew stronger than ever; twice the Crusade were called in English name, and twice it succeeded in distracting enemy from England's grand plan. The will of England is the will of Europe, and by extension; Papalcy.History is shaped by English hand.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												This game is probably one of the best Total War games to date. It takes the simplicity and fun from Rome and provided the much-needed improvements that are still present in the new games, such as recruiting more than one unit at a time and implementing actual fighting animations rather than just watching some Principes poke the air in front of some hoplites. Great game over all and a ton of fun to get in to, though the relations between nations and the random declarations of war tied with the fact that the starting nations are limited by threats of excommunications sometimes makes me want to cringe. Definitely a must-have for Total War fans and history geeks alike.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2011
												Although i personally prefer the newer, Shogun Total war installment of the series. This game has definitely got to be up there as one of the best games i have ever played, and especially as a strategy game. Medieval 2 definitely satisfies more than one of the gaming tastebuds, with great gameplay whilst also being a rather pretty game to look at, with its rather impressive graphics. I would reccomend this game to anyone interested in the franchise, who loves strategy games and also to anyone who loves a certain aura of historical accuracy in terms of certain events and being able to play key historical battles. ALSO this game has some pretty nifty mods and expansion packs available so although the story will end. It will take a bloody long time to get there so you can be sattisfied for hours on end. Personally i reccomend getting hold of the Kingdoms expansion and then downloading the Third Age Total War mod, because it is bloody epic!  8/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
												Medieval 2, like any game in Total War series combines Global Campaign strategy with individual battle tactics. So far, it's the only series that do justice to the concept. It leaves a special feeling as you build up cities and castles, hire armies and send them out on conquests or to defend your own lands. Game maintains the sence of epicness in every aspect, from your expansion across Europe to massive battle where thousands of soldiers face of against each other. Though the "thousands" part is dependant on what setting you select in unit scale option.While the only competitor to this game is only the later installments of Total War series, so many  flaws arise as you progress through the campaigns:  The AI is overly poor. Both in battles and campaign.  Diplomacy is rudimentary at best.  As you expand, your play session becomes a micromanagerial nightmare.  Attacking and defending castles, rather than playing out as multilevel dramas where armies fall back to secondary gates, or fight for each cross street, turn out to be decided at the main gate or outer wall. The complexity of highly developed citadels seems like a wasted opportunity.   Religion and Pope mechanism while novel at first, later on either becomes too easy to exploit or an absolute niusance.With all it's flaws and shortcommings, unfortunatelly there isn't a better game of this nature. Not outside Total War series atleast.
